Biblical Buddies is a roll-and-move game, with each player working towards reaching the end of the track first. Many spaces on the board have instructions to either help you move forward faster or to go back, lose a turn, etc. As players traverse the board they will read about many different biblical characters. A provided information booklet allows the player to find out more about each character and the role they played in the biblical stories.

name: Treasure Tide
description:
Description from the publisher:

Treasure Tide is an arcade-style plunder-pushing game that has players racing to collect the most loot from a wrecked pirate ship. Gather gold, gems and perhaps pieces of the fabled buried treasure map!

name: Grossburgers
description:
In Grossburgers, you are a line cook in a 1950's hamburger joint. Your job is to serve as many burgers as you can, no matter how gross the ingredients. In fact, depending on the customer, the grosser the better.

Grossburgers is a real time dice rolling game about building and selling burgers. Players, at the same time, roll their dice trying to get sets of icons to do different actions in the game. When one player has an action that requires them to ring the bell, everyone must pause play and let them perform their action. Then that player rings the bell and everyone can start
rolling their dice and performing actions again.

Players will fulfill customer orders with ingredients ranging from classic to grossout! Ingredients on burgers are worth points at the end of the game but watch out for grossouts because they will cause you to score negative points.

Grossburgers is a fast and frenzied game of burger building madness!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Killer Dice
description:
Description from the designer:

What it is:
Killer Dice is a quick and easy dice rolling game for two or more people that plays in less than 10 minutes.

What you get:
Killer Dice comes with 6 dice of different colors, 2 sets of dice labels (in case things get messy), 5 red damage counters, directions, and a drawstring bag to hold all your goodies together.

What you do:
Each player takes a single turn of five rolls of the included dice. After each roll, the rolling player may choose to use one rolled special ability to affect the roll results or damage the Killer Die. They then remove any eliminated victim dice from the game. The player then rolls again until they either complete five rolls, run out of victim dice, or chase off the Killer Die by dealing at least 5 damage.

How you win:
After each player has taken their turn of five rolls, the player with the most surviving victim dice is declared the winner. In case of a tie, the player who also dealt the most damage to the Killer Die wins. If no player has any surviving dice, the Killer Die wins.
categories: Dice, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Derelict
description:
Description from the publisher:

In Derelict, you are a Space Marine detailed to protect a science team. This team has discovered an artifact orbiting Taurus III, a distant planet located millions of light years from Earth. Initially, there was no sign of anything wrong.

The artifact changed that.

You watch, horrified, as the scientists you swore to protect quickly turn into the stuff of nightmares. The infected crewmembers grow massive scythe-like claws where their arms used to be, razor sharp fangs in place of teeth, and horns now protrude through the skin all over their tortured bodies. These poor souls now only have a singular mission: kill anything in their path.

As the last healthy human aboard, you need to focus on surviving long enough to get the hell out of here!

Derelict is a game for 2-5 players divided into two asymmetrical teams. One player is the human, tasked with restoring the derelict space ship to working order and escaping an untimely end. The other team plays as the infested, who make up the remainder of the players, and have only one goal: kill the human player at all costs!
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: The Great Wall Of Mexico
description:
Description from the publisher:

We are proud to present our game "The Great Wall of Mexico" with your favorite, and maybe not-so-favorite characters. This is a game of fun and surprises, and an epic battle to build or destroy a wall between Mexico and the United States of America.

More than anything else, this is a game full of humor that will make you and your friends laugh. This is a simple game, and you don't have to know anything about or even care about politics to enjoy this game.

The game starts with a wall half built (or half destroyed if you will). If all the bricks are in place - team orange wins. If all the bricks are gone - team green wins.

The bricks are added or removed after every round, depending on which team wins. The card values are added together and if the score is above zero 0 the green team wins and removes a brick. If not - the orange team does and adds one.

name: Colores
description:
Game contents:
4 boards 25 Instruction Cards 48 Walkers in 4 different colors Instruction page in Hebrew and English

The game's objective:
To be the first player who accumulates 6 Walkers in his chosen color.

What is the game's contribution to us and to our children?
Playing this game strengthens our thinking process and perceptivity skills, it also improves our hand movements, its speed and the attention to small details, and finally it creates a colorful and familial experience with great fun.
Strengthens thinking process…
Improves hand movements and speed…
Ready, set…
And here we go…

—description from the publisher

name: Aussie Rules Football Game
description:
"Great fun for all the family all the year oval."

In The Aussie Rules Football Game two coaches roll a die to move the football around the field. Scoring is in the fashion of Australian Rules Football, 6 points for a goal, 1 point for a behind. The game is played over four quarters each of five minutes duration, the team that scores the most points wins.

name: Vanpi-ru
description:
User summary
ヴァンピール (Vanpi-ru) is a Werewolf-style game with one player being the Vampire and the others as villagers. Players are working to get their colour to be the strongest by playing cards to the table. However, villagers can be infected to become a Vampire and can be cured (the original Vampire is immune).

name: Top Cop
description:
From publisher site:

Fast action, as cops patrol the city on a crime wave alert!

With cops playing as pieces, players search for clues to capture 9 criminals on the WANTED list. Clues found on patrol are pegged on the Big City game board. 1st to capture 3 robbers is TOP COP.

Synopsis:
On your turn, if there are not 3 "WANTED Posters" (cards) displayed, you draw one from the tray. There must always be 3 WANTED Posters displayed at all times during the game. You move your piece along the board, collecting clues on the spaces where you land, and match the clues up with items from the WANTED Posters. Once you have collected all 3 clues from one of the Posters, you have caught the criminal in that poster. The first player to capture 3 criminals is the TOP COP.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Emblems: NHL
description: Emblems: NHL is a set-collecting and trick-taking — or hat trick-taking, wink wink — card game that focuses on the grouping of NHL teams and logos. Players call out attributes of specific logos – such as year, Stanley Cups, or colors – and collect as many cards as possible. They can earn additional points along the way by using special in-game and end-game bonus cards that will boost their total score. The player with the highest score wins.

name: Land of Medievals: Mounts & Armor
description:
Mounts & Armor is a 42 card expansion set for Land of Medievals.
This expansion brings you two new types of cards and expands the
game difficulty, gameplay time and strategies.
each mount type has different skills and the army units can now earn and wear epic armors to block and deflect received damages.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Medieval, Mythology, Print & Play
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination

name: Imperium Chronicles: Theater of Operations – Boarding Actions
description:
Theater of Operations: Boarding Actions portrays tactical combat between boarding parties attacking enemy ships in the Imperium Chronicles universe.

One player takes the role of the Imperium while the other player controls the Magna Supremacy. The game can be played using individual scenarios or players may choose to use resource points to “buy” their forces before the game begins. Units include regular crew members, security, marines, heavy marines, and turrets.

Theater of Operations: Boarding Actions is designed with ease of play in mind, including rules that are simple to learn and execute.

Features:

Three full-color ship maps in 1" scale
Five general unit types including regular crew, security, marines, heavy marines, and turrets
Three special attributes: Leader, Medic, Demolition
Individual weapon types including small arms, shotguns, hand grenades, and grenade launchers
800+ ship counters (full-strength & wounded sides)
Straight-forward rules for fast gameplay
categories: Miniatures, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Loaded Iron
description:
Description from the publisher:

A clock shows 4:55am

Yard Boss
“I see a couple new faces here today. Nice. So Here's the drill. Contracts come in for freight and passengers every morning starting at 5am. Trains need to be loaded and out of here by 5:30. You have exactly 30 mins to complete your tasks. It is YOUR job to see that ALL contracts are fulfilled. GOT IT?!?”

“More than that, make sure you make the railyard money or you are sacked! Every locomotive, and car you use needs to be fully loaded, or it will cost you your job. And one more thing, don’t overload my trains. Locomotives can only pull so much. You blow one of my engines and I will become seriously unpleasant.”

“Any questions?”

"No?"

“Excellent"

“One more thing to remember, as departure time draws nearer and you see you don’t have enough capacity to fill all your contracts, you can always sub them out to one of these mates standing next to you. You may not get paid for that contract, but it won't count against you when the whistle blows. You and I get paid when the contracts get filled so make sure there are no contracts in your hand when the whistle blows.“

“Now get out there and make me some money!”

Gameplay is as follow:
Players start with 10 train cards. Each turn they can either draw 3 cards or play 3 cards. In order to play cards, you must first play a locomotive and coal car. Then additional car and cargo can be played. The correct train car needs to be played in order to place cargo and cargo is the only way to make money. In the end, if time and running out and there is cargo you cant play, then subcontract it onto another player's train. You may not get the money for it, but it wont cost you double in the end. You also might just fill a spot on an opponent's train that they needed.

name: Cantonese
description:
A GAME OF CANTONESE RICE - Get your chopsticks ready!
The wooden ingredients of A game of Cantonese rice are made of wood coming from eco-friendly forestry in respect of the natural and social environment.
A game of Cantonese rice is a safe, eco-friendly game realised with nontoxic paint and made in Italy
COMPONENTS:
1 large bowl
2 small bowls
250 wooden kernels (rice)
21 green wooden spheres (peas)
20 pink wooden cubes (ham)
20 yellow wooden discs (eggs)
2 pairs of bamboo chopsticks**
NR. OF PLAYERS: 2
RECOMMENDED AGE: 5 +

INSTRUCTIONS:
Each players receives a bowl and a pair of chopsticks, while the ingredients (rice, peas, ham and eggs) are mixed together in the big bowl, which must be placed between the two players.
Ready, steady, go!
Using only the chopsticks, each player tries to take as many coloured ingredients as possible from the big bowl to put them in their small bowl. The winner is the player who gets the most coloured ingredients!

name: Turtle Challenge
description:
TURTLECHALLENGE - Unbelievably agile turtles take on amazing challenges!
Whose turtle will get closest to the Giant Rock? Whose tower will be the tallest?
The turtles are made of wood coming from eco-friendly forestry in respect of the natural and social environment.
Turtle challenge is a safe, eco-friendly game realised with nontoxic paint and made in Italy.

COMPONENTS:
8 wooden turtles in two colours (4 green, 4 orange)
1 wooden rock
NR. OF PLAYERS: 2
RECOMMENDED AGE: 4 +
INSTRUCTIONS:
turtle run: Test your dexterity! Slide your turtle as close to the Giant Rock as possible in this new take on bowls. The closest one wins!
turtle tower: Test your balancing skills! Try to place the most turtles on top of the Giant Rock. The winner is the player who makes the highest tower without it falling!

name: Wellington Rules
description:
From the back cover
Wellington Rules is a set of rules designed to fight tactical engagements during the Napoleonic Wars. Wellington Rules is designed so that each player would control approximately a brigade of troops.
In Wellington Rules players command brigades and divisions in small tactical actions of the Napoleonic Wars.
Players will find that Wellington Rules makes the command of these elements challenging and fun while the streamlined, consistent mechanics makes the game easy to learn and simple to play. With Wellington Rules you can concentrate on tactics, not charts.

Scales:
1 infantry or cavalry figure = 30 men,
1 cannon casting = 2 guns,
1 gunner figure = 10 men,
1 inch = 15 yards,
1 turn = 15 minutes

name: Big Battles for Little Hands: Wargaming Source Book for Children
description:
Description from the back of the book:

This book is an introduction to the hobby of playing tabletop battles with miniatures. This a fun, interesting and educational pastime for children of all ages. This book traces its roots from games played by H.G. Wells and R.L. Stevenson in their backyards around the turn of the century.
Big Battles is meant to be a sourcebook, a great deal of information has been packed into it. Big Battles for Little Hands includes:

An introduction to wargamming

A brief history of land warfare

A primer on tactics

A complete set of rules for playing battles: Milk and Cookie Rules

A complete set of rules for playing skirmishes: Blood and Swash

Scenarios

Guides on where to find model soldiers

An introductory guide on how to paint soldiers

A guide for parents

and much more...

name: B.A.P.U.C. (Beer and Pretzels Urban Combat)
description:
Beer and Pretzels Urban Combat (B.A.P.U.C.) is a simple, fast-playing skirmish war game using modern small arms in a hypothetical future of civilian urban warfare, using a card based turn sequence. Players agree on the size of each army made up of urban guerillas (typical scenario calls for any guerilla troop of five to eleven guerillas, though enough tokens are available to field 18 guerillas per side). Players also agree on weapon equipment ranging from pistols to machine guns and grenade launchers. Using a shuffled deck of standard playing cards, turns are determined by the draw of the cards – red cards allow the red force to move, while black cards allow the blue force to move.
Combat is based on the individual guerilla with a health of four points each.
Optional rules include Personalized Guerilla leaders, each with their own special rules.
Six scenarios are provided with the game, each with their own victory condition and rules for the scenario. One of the scenarios is designed for four players, while the largest scenario (22 guerillas in combat) plays in about 30 minutes.

Rules are only five pages long and includes double-sides reference chart for weapons and movement effects, two additional pages of optional rules, a diagram illustrating valid attacks, and a sheet containing the six scenarios. The game comes with a preprinted hex-based game map and an uncut token sheet for fire effects and guerillas for both red and blue forces.

name: The Battle of the River Plate
description:
The Battle of the River Plate is a tactical game of the December 13, 1939, engagement between the German cruiser Admiral Graf Spee and its British pursuers, the Ajax, Achilles, and Exeter. Components consist of a rules booklet, a Combat Card, four ship-armor diagram cards, plastic blocks labeled as the ships, and blocks in several colors use to designate hits.

The game is intended to be played on a hex board supplied by the owner. The rules specify use of an Avalon Hill Stalingrad board so that starting hexes can be specified in terms of Stalingrad locations. Pieces use both hexes and hexsides for movement to double the number of possible facing directions.

Movement is plotted and executed simultaneously. Rules cover gunfire, torpedoes, smokescreens, and ammunition supply. There is no time limit; play continues until the Graf Spee escapes or is sunk.

The stated purpose of the game is to "introduce the designers method of naval combat". Five years later Bruce Moore published the better known game Early Pacific Battles.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: PLANESS
description:
User summary
PLANESS is a territory occupation game with a theme of space exploration.

There is a virtual square grid on the table, and each player places their space ship on the grid at the beginning of the game.

Each turn, your space ship moves several squares on the grid. For each square you passed, if it is unoccupied by any player, you place your planet chip on the square to indicate that this planet is yours. You may add mores chip on your planet by passing the same square again.

You may also pass an opponent's planet. In this case, the topmost chip on the square is removed, and if this make the square empty, you place your planet chip to indicate you have taken over the control of the planet.

Players count their victory points at the end of the game. You score big points if you have a large contiguous area of your planets. The highest scorer wins the game.

Publisher's summary
惑星探索をテーマにした陣取りゲーム。
ゲーム終了時に最も得点が高いプレイヤーの勝利。
自分の惑星を確保しつつ、相手の惑星を奪い、破壊することが勝利の鍵。
チーム戦も可能。
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Team-Based Game
publishers: Board Game Parfait (ボードゲームパフェ)

name: Emergency Treatment Center
description:
A Co-operative Game with an emergency-room simulation theme.

Gameplay is cooperative. Players are all on the same team and take turns being team leader. Players take decisions on who to admit to an emergency room bed, how to distribute limited resources of skilled personnel to address injuries. Game mechanisms control the flow of patients, nurses, doctors and time. Beds are limited, injuries vary from critical to nominal. Patients have varied age range and varied gender/appearence.

The goal is to treat as many patients in one 8-hour shift as possible. Players do not win or lose, but treating all 15 patients is a perfect game, leaving some patients for the next shift is to be avoided if possible.

name: Figure & ground
description:
City Development game

game-play
Each turn draw a map tile, and place it with others map tile(s). If the map tiles form a 2/3 circle, you can draw a extra map tile from supply.
Then for each circle you form, you can gain 1 building tiles.
You can change city cards by building tiles.

goal
Be the first player collect 3 city cards.

name: Skeeing
description:
This is a dexterity game with an unusual box. It is hinged on one side, and when opens, creates an extended lithographed playing field. The bottom of the box has a ramp starting at the hinge, and five scoring slots on the far side (worth 10, 20 and 50 points).

Players take turns shooting marbles from the top end, over the ski jump and (hopefully) into one of the scoring slots. Player with the highest total score for six marbles wins.

This game was produced by the German publisher Klee, but the box says "Made in Bavaria" and bears the company's early "Clover" international logo (Klee is German for Clover). While undated, this certainly means it was published after Moritz Bromeisl joined the company in 1915 and began moving it into international markets, and probably between the end of WWI and the early 1920s.

name: Animals with Weapons
description:
Description from the publisher:

A shark vs manatee? No contest. A shark with a pool cue vs manatee with a bazooka? Interesting... A couple of billion years ago, evolution (or whatever) invented animals. A couple of million years ago our pre-human ancestors invented weapons. A couple of minutes ago we gave the former access to the latter.

Animals with Weapons is a casual card game for 2-4 players. It develops the idea of the traditional trump-card game by incorporating two main decks (Animals and Weapons), along with a 'sub-deck' of Terrain cards, which are combined to make animal/weapon combos. This eliminates much of the repetition of traditional trump-card games and allows strong weapons to compensate for weak animals. A 'capture or loot' mechanic also removes the stalemate which so often develops in trump-card games.

132 cards, with 60 animals in each of the main decks, makes for 3600 combinations in the base game, with multiple game modes to broaden gameplay.

Designed to be played in under half an hour, AWW is quick, brutal and very silly.

name: Churchill Checkers
description:
This all-wood game was published in Canada in 1943, clearly cashing in on the popularity of the British wartime Prime Minister. The solid wood board shows a circle with 4 concentric rings divided by 10 radii. There is a centre space marked with a Crown, and each of the 41 resulting spaces has a hole into which a wooden peg can be placed. There is a hole in the side of the board stopped with a cork in which 20 pegs are stored.

Each player starts with 10 pegs, placed in the outer two rings of half the circle. The pegs start with a plain side up, and are marked with the player's colour (red or black) on the other end.

Players move alternately, either clockwise, counter-clockwise or toward the centre. As in normal checkers, they must jump over an opponent into a vacant space if able to do so. A piece moving or jumping into the Crown space at the centre flips into a King, which is then allowed to move and jump outward as well as inward. A piece in the Crown space is safe, and only a King can jump back into the Crown space and continue jumping.

Normally, a player wins be eliminating the opponent's pieces, but there also are rules for a "losing" game where the objective is to give away all your pieces or create a situation where you are unable to move.

While the rules show the publisher as London Novelty and Display Products, the box says it was manufactured by Robinson Industrial - Crafts Limited, also of London, Canada.

name: Samurai Punk
description:
Unleash spectacular combos and devastating finishing moves in this jaw-dropping, butt-kicking fighting game of martial arts mash-ups! For 2-4 players.

In Samurai Punk, players assume the role of deadly warriors in an original world that blends steampunk with martial arts - samurais, ninjas, kung-fu monks, gangsters, gunslingers, knights templar, and more! Combining a Fighter deck and a Sensei deck, players create a unique fighting duo to duel against their opponents.

Combos are formed by pairing a sensei's Style cards with a fighter's Strike cards, creating one of thousands of different moves, like "Flying Kick", "Fierce Defensive Slash", and "Ultra Spinning Dragon Uppercut". Each round, new Styles or Strikes are played, replacing some cards in the players' Combos while retaining the others. Used cards store up Chi energy which can activate special abilities, making every card count. Master your duo's unique strategies and versatile combos to out-fight your opponents to victory!
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Renaissance, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Hand Management, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Triolett
description:
There are 3 game variations, all on the same game board. Two players Play with 12 playing pieces each.

A. Einkreisungsspiel Maja
One playing Piece of each player is called the "Maja". Which one is hidden from the Opponent (marked on the bottom). The players try to encircle the enemy pieces. Encircled pieces are taken out of the game. If the black Maja is encircled on a yellow space it may reenter the game, but if it ist encircled on a blue space the opponent has won the game. The opposite is true for the white Maja.

B. Rösselpunktspiel
The pieces start at one edge of the game board and have to reach the opposite edge. The pieces move like a chess knight. The first player to get all 12 pieces to the opposite side of the game board wins the game.

C. Türmerspiel
The pieces start at one edge of the game board and have to reach the opposite edge to turn into towers. The pieces move any number of spaces in all directions. Opposite pieces can be taken by skipping over the piece sideways to a free space directly behind it.
Pieces that reach the opposite edge of the game board, get turned into a tower by stacking a second piece on top of it. Towers may take enemy pieces (or Towers) by skipping over them not only to the space directly behind the taken piece but to several spaces behind, if there are no other pieces or towers in-between. The last player to have any playing pieces on the board wins the game.

name: Somme: Life in the Saps
description:
A simple yet engaging, tactical trench warfare card game themed around the misery and glory, the hope and despair of one the most historic battles in human history i.e. World War I - Battle of the Somme. It features a patently new and unique COVER AND REQUISITION wargaming system that allows for:

1. 2 player fast paced action
2. Tactical turn-based strategy
3. Grinding trench warfare
4. Simple game mechanics
5. Easy to learn
6. Quick setup
7. Challenging gameplay
8. Suitability for ages 10+
9. Short 15 minutes playtime
10. and much more!

Somme: The Story

The year is 1916. A great war rages across the world. “The war to end all wars” some call it and it seems to be living up to its name, for a more terrible yet strange war the mankind had not seen before.

It is definitely nothing like those that came before it, for here the men lie, waiting, almost peacefully, in the lines they have drawn. For months together, nothing has stirred over the now, black land. No bird flies over, nor any beast roams here. The silence is almost unbearable, as the men eat, sleep and go about their business in absolute monotony.

Suddenly, the frail sense of security is shattered by a deafening noise, as a bombshell explodes nearby, causing the men to drop their jobs and scuttle for cover. One explosion is followed by another and another and another… and so the pounding goes on and on… for days and days… till all nerves are frayed and every muscle is jittery. Just when they were beginning to think that it would never stop, it ends, as abruptly, as it had started.

Deafened by the onslaught on their ears, the soldiers strain to hear, fearful of that which is to follow. Soon enough, they hear a distant pattering of feet, getting closer and closer or are they? Surely, it is the sound of gunfire that they hear now or are their ears still playing tricks on them? The men arise as if from a great slumber and peer over the parapet. What they see is incredulous, for what was earlier a barren wasteland is now a rising sea before them. Their knuckles whiten as they tighten their grips over their weapons and wait for the incoming tide to draw closer, nay, wash over them.

It is clear, that thousands will die this day and whether or not they themselves would survive, will ultimately depend on your wisdom, as their commander and the support of the brothers, by their sides. So take charge and stand fast. For the empire!

Somme: The game

Setup: To play, each player chooses and commandeers a faction, the British or the German, consisting of a squad of 6 soldiers that are laid out in a couple of trench lines on the table. From among the rest of the shuffled cards, 20 cards are passed between the players and 10 are drafted by each player. Of these 6, are assigned to the soldiers already on the table while the rest 4 are held in the player’s hand as faction reserve. 2 cards are opened at the draw pile to form the common supply line.

Strategy: Each of the fighting units under the player’s command has a different loadout and a susceptibility to specific hardship cards. Further, the unit loadouts keep changing over the game and may also be affected by unveiling of certain event cards. The crux of the game's strategy however lies in bidding from the supply line which will ultimately decide the actions available in the future.

Objective: The object of the game is simple, eliminate the rival faction before they eliminate you.

Turn Mechanics: The play alternates between the players as they play cards from their reserve to the Personnel Cards in the trench lines seeking to form compatible sets of Attack-Defence Cards in order to launch attacks, counter-attacks or to defend. Dictated by the ensuing card play outcomes, the soldiers may either loose morale, gain morale or be eliminated. At the end of each turn, both the players may bid to draft the available replacement cards from the common supply line as they prepare to face another sapping day in the trenches. Thus, the grinding battle continues, till only one side remains standing.
categories: Card Game, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Simulation

name: Lockdown!
description:
The penitentiary is in chaos. Prisoners are on the loose and rioting, and it’s your job to restore order. To make matters more difficult, the inmates are grouped into seven factions, and you have to round up as many of these gang members as you can to have any hope of success.

Lockdown! is a streamlined, themed version of the card game Canasta, specifically designed for two players. The 64-card deck consists of 49 Gang cards and 15 Special cards. Major improvements include simplified scoring and opportunities for cunning card play.

One of the problems with Canasta is that the player (or team) which takes the inevitable, massive discard pile will usually win the round. In Lockdown!, discard piles are far more manageable, and you can even remove up to two of them from the game! (Don't worry, there's a counter to this.) Additionally, four cards will score a meld (as opposed to seven in Canasta), and of course there are incentives to go higher than four.

Lockdown! plays quickly, and most of the rules are on the cards for easy reference. First player to 100 wins the game!

name: Adventure Time: The Epic Gassy Jake Game
description:
A Gassy twist to the fun game of Hot Potato Game. Soft plush Jake doll with 4 different electronic "pooting" sounds. Great for both indoor & outdoor play. Quickly toss Gassy Jake from player to player and don't be caught holding Jake as he emits his gassy sounds. If you do, your out. There are 4 electronic "pooting" sounds emitted by randomized timer. So you don't know when the sounds are going to be automatically activated. The featured authentic sounds are "as heard on" the actual show episodes. There are several ways to play for different skill levels. WARNING:: THIS GAME IS CAPABLE OF MAKING YOU LAUGH UNCONTROLLABLY.

—description from the publisher

name: Zombie Hour
description:
A Game of Survival in the Zombie Apocalypse

From the introduction:

The apocalypse has come. The dead have risen. Time is running out for the human race. Only a few survive. Against a rising tide of zombies, a small group of stubborn humans spitefully carries on, scavenging the ruins of the city looking for supplies to bring back to their fortified base where they hide from death.

But for how long?

Time, not the undead, is your greatest enemy.

User summary:

The game is played in turns, with each player moving first and the zombies appearing and moving in an end-of-turn phase. Characters have several tracked attributes. The map of the area is developed during play by placing cards. Game time is limited to one hour. Victory is collaborative and depends on accomplishing certain scavenge and survival goals before time expires. A separate, optional, rating method is provided to determine "who on your team finishes on top", in the case of victory.

The game document includes several pages of print-and-play components.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Symphony of Pain
description:
A board game originally published in Games Workshop's White Dwarf magazine (2014 issue #34 of White Dwarf.)

In the dark, unseen dungeons of Commorragh Haemonculus Covens gather to celebrate the perfection of pain in brutal contests against one another. These affairs are brutal and bloody, but for the lords of torture and rejuvenation, every new sensation is one to be cherished.

Symphony of Pain is a game for 2-4 players where each player controls a small team of five Wracks and a Haemonculus in a fight to inflict the most pain on the enemy.

There are two ways to win Symphony of Pain: eliminate all of the opposing models or gain enough pain points to declare yourself the winner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination

name: The Defence of Athel Loren
description:
A board game originally published in Games Workshop's White Dwarf magazine (2014 issue #14 of White Dwarf)

The Defence of Athel Loren is a simple minigame that uses a Treeman and five Warhammer warriors who seek to despoil the home of the Wood Elves.

There are two players in this game, the Defender and the Despoiler. The object of the game is for the Defender to use his Treeman to kill the Despoiler’s minions before they can reach the Sacred Glade of Athel Loren.

name: What Time Is It?
description: This well-designed game will get kids up to speed on telling time. Players move the arms on their own clock faces to show the time described on cards. It is especially good for correlating analog and digital representations of time as well as wording like half past and quarter to. Cards are color coded for the progression of skills in learning to tell time; each color representing time to the hour, the half hour, the quarter hour, in five minute intervals or for all sixty minutes. Points are awarded for setting clocks to the correct time, as well as for correcting clocks to the specified time, making playing a reinforcement of time telling skills.

name: Steal all the Cake
description:
Steal all the Cake is a 2 to 4 player card game of remarkable thievery where players dispatch hordes of cute mischievous animals to steal mountains of cake from eachother.

Players can eat their cake to harness its mighty powers but if they are not careful they might find themselves with an empty plate.

Each turn players can send one animal and eat one cake, each type of card has various effects that will bring you closer to victory.

The goal of the game is to Steal all the Cake.

If a player runs out of cake they lose and they are out, so they must learn the balance between stealing, hoarding and devouring cake.

The last player standing wins and is crowned the King of Thieves!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Fantasy, Party Game
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Player Elimination

name: The Emperor's Samurai
description:
The Emperor's Samurai is a tactical/action game set in ancient Japan. Players control 1 of 4 samurai from competing clans, in an attempt to earn honor through retrieval of the Emperor's stolen items and captives. They must enter the Mongol Warlords dungeon, and maneuver the shifting passageways before the entire dungeon caves in! All while surviving encounters from the opposing samurai and a deadly assassin who watches over the dungeon.

The object of the game is to secure the most honor. Players collect honor by picking up tokens, fighting opposing samurai and entering the vault. When players reach their carry limit, they'll want to exit out any stairway, thus securing their honor and preventing other players the opportunity to take it!

Opposing samurai can be extremely dangerous but the assassin who watches over the Warlords dungeon can be even more deadly! His movements are quick and unpredictable. Players will be using action cards to evade the assassin, attack opposing samurai, and manipulate the dungeon paths.

As the game progresses, the Warlord begins caving in the stairways and eventually the vault, thus funneling the players and ramping up the action! The game ends when all carried honor is secured.

The samurai with the most honor earns the privilege of becoming a member of The Emperor's Samurai!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Take That, Tile Placement

name: Saber of London
description:
Based on the 1950's TV series of the same name. It is a detective game with some similarities to Cluedo in that the aim of the game is to identify the murderer.
Up to 4 players use a telephone shaped spinner to move around the board collecting clues. Clues are recorded on crime sheets and the first player to correctly identify the murderer is the winner.
The board comprises of 6 bedrooms, a bathroom, reception and Sabers office. Squares around these rooms allow players to move around the board depending on the number they spin.
There are 4 wooden playing pieces and a spinner. There are 6 card men (one of which is the murderer) and a card body (a woman). The card men are stood in wooden blocks. There are also 6 clues cards (only 5 used in any one game) and 6 cards keys, silvered on one side and with a letter referring to a bedroom on the other.

name: Bushido: Shuichi
description:
The Takashi clan have long followed the teachings of Michi and unlike some of the other clans in the Jwar Isles strictly adhere to its teachings when raising the next generation. The Michi priests already offer the support of their military arm in the form of the Seishin na Geoi, but are not opposed to accompanying any believes on their paths, whether that leads them to battle or otherwise. Through years of dedication the Michi priests are able to evoke the protective powers of their ancestors, dousing flame, neutralising poisons or the intrusive commands of others. The presence of the spirits can also be used to distract and block the concentration of enemies.

Blister contains one model, one 30mm base and one full colour profile card.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Kioshi Makoto
description:
“Like all the cycles of the world, those within the Golden Empire are no different. From the changing of the cycles to the rise and fall of the great clans that rule, so is the way things are, and so is the way they will remain for they are as constant as rock and as inevitable as the stream that finds the ocean.” Common Subarashi Baransu saying.

All the great clans draw on the lesser clans for support, either on the battlefield, in court or commercially, the Takashi are no different and for many generations the Makoto have enjoyed the protection of the Takashi in exchange for their wisdom and consort. The Makoto family are renowned for their wealth of knowledge and love of the sciences. Kioshi has long been the voice of reason in the court of Ryu, his quiet words hold more weight than Minimoto steel to the heads of the Takashi.

Blister contains one model, one 30mm base and one full colour profile card.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Galaxy Rise
description:
Hidden identities with opposing goals compete for trick-taking galaxy supremacy!

Players are given hidden identity cards: The "Envoy" scores points for other people making their bid, the "Saboteur" scores for others failing, and everybody else scores for making their own. The deck size changes depending on the player count (3, 4, or 5) so every game is balanced.

After being dealt their hands and hidden identities, each player bids the number of tricks they will take using gems. Color-coded gems make it easy to see if the bid is under, full, or over. One player may be a saboteur, so you cannot count on every bid being legitimate.

The hand is played out in trick. The Solar suit is always trump. As players take tricks they place their gems on the piles so the status of all bids is apparent to all. After the last trick is taken every player reveals their identity and scores points accordingly. Players move their corresponding cube on the score track until one player makes it to 30 points to win the game.

STORY

Centuries of multilateral conflicts throughout the galaxy are being resolved at the diplomatic conference of the era: The Congress of Zienna. Borderlines will be drawn and the resources of entire systems will be acquired. Empires, alliances, and multi-planetery corporations struggle for power --- not in battle but at the negotiating table.

You are a representative of a galactic power sent to Zienna Prime. Your goal at the negotiating table depends on your hidden identity:

Envoy - Galactic peace alliances benefit from stability and mutual success. The Envoy's goal is to help all parties get what they want.

Saboteur - Hired by nefarious provocateurs seeking conflict, the saboteur is sent to prevent the negotiations from being a success.

Solo Agent - Representing the interests of a single client state or corporation, agents work to maximise acquisitions with no regard for competitors.

name: Blindes Huhn extrem: Tauschen
description:
Blindes Huhn extrem: Tauschen is a promotional card for Blindes Huhn extrem that allows you to change your hand with another player.

Designer Michael Schacht released Blindes Huhn extrem: Tauschen as one-half of a postcard Christmas card (the other half containing Maharaja: Reichtum).

name: TradeWorlds: Roles Compendium
description:
Description from the publisher:

A "core" set expansion that is designed to primarily alter the turn order of the game. Tired of going around in circles?! This expansion features Premium Role cards that change the turn order. How it works? At the beginning of each round, players secretly choose a Premium Role card. That will be the role they are using on their next turn. Players then simultaneously reveal their role and the order is determined from Highest to Lowest ensuring that the game rounds are always different.

In addition to the Premium Role cards, also included are two (2) expansion Scenarios: Rise of the Monarch and Battle Front.

As per the original one (1) Player Game Sets, the Rise of the Monarch scenario is back! This scenario brings back the days of early Renaissance and exploration of the Galaxy. In this scenario, players race to be the first player to earn the right to be the Monarch Supreme of the galaxy.

The newer addition to the expansion is the Battle Front scenario. This scenario's goal is to accelerate and shorten the time spent playing the Spacewars scenario. It can be played as a scenario itself OR as another expansion played together with any of the current multiplayer scenarios (Tradewars, Spacewars or Rise of the Monarch). In this scenario, players race to obtain "retrofits" for their starships which will give them bonus effects to alter the way space skirmishes are resolved. There are a total of six (6) different "retrofits" available to each player. Much like the Days of Glory scenario, the retrofits are unlocked as a player earns more credits.

Also as one of the game's Stretch Goals, we've added a Co-op scenario called United Garrison in which up to four (4) players can combat a Derelict starship that is hell bent on destroying all the player's Homeworlds.

This expansion is comprised of 96 cards for 1 to 4 Players. It can add from 15-30 minutes of additional game time to the "core" game.
categories: Dice, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Trading

name: TradeWorlds: Planetary Expansion
description:
Description from the publisher:

A "core" set expansion that is designed to increase the level of strategy by adding Tradeships and Trade Agreements. It features the Mission cards that were removed from the original one (1) Player Box Set due to complexity and an attempt to "streamline" the original game for a wider gamer audience.

Missions are back and therefore so are Tradeships. Tradeships allow you to perform a mission which may take 1 to 5 turns to complete, during this time the player on a mission will benefit from a Trade Agreement which will give them bonus credits when banking certain resources. Modifiers are 2x, +5 and 3x the value of the banked resource (according to the Trade Agreement).

This expansion is comprised of 140 cards for 1 to 4 Players. It also adds 4 white custom dice to be used as counters for Tradeships. It can add from 15-30 minutes of additional game time to the "core" game. However, this is offset by higher banking of resources, which ultimately balances the duration of the game.
categories: Dice, Economic, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Trading

name: 9 Below
description: Take that game similar to a 3x3 Golf with card interactions.

name: Jusenkyo Panic: Race to the Top
description:
An insert game from the December Holiday issue of Animerica Magazine. Volume 2, issue 12. Players race to the finish while trying not to land in a pool or get knocked back by other players. Combat is with cards with the highest tally winning a duel.

From the magazine index.

Now everyone has a chance to get their head wet! You've watched the video and read the comic. ..now it's time to play the board game! A hybrid of popular collectible card games such as
Magic: The Gathering and the children's classic Chutes and Ladders, Jusenkyo Panic: Race to the Top! is a wild ride through some very wet country as you fight (and fight and fight and fight) to reach the infamous Chinese Training Ground of Cursed Springs, Jusenkyo, before it's too late.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Racing
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Republica de Bananes
description:
Republica de Bananes is a 3-8 player free-for-all card game, set in a banana republic during the height of the Cold War. Players take on the role of the county’s ruling politicians. Their goal is to achieve a secret Ulterior Motive, while stopping their opponents achieving their own, all while trying to rule the country.

Ulterior Motives include seizing the presidency with the support of a paricular faction, embezzling the nation's budget, manipulating the nation into becoming an outpost of the US or USSR, or causing outright civil war and benefiting from the ensuing chaos.

During a turn each player takes four actions, using cards drawn from the Power deck, and other options based on the political landscape of the nation, such as its current Stability, and the levels of foreign influence. These actions include playing Supporter cards to increase their personal strength, and activating abilities, which can improve their position or hinder an opponent. Some abilities have broader effects, changing the political climate for all players.

Elections and Coups are a key part of the game. Each turn players jockey for political power, and often must rely on the support of their rivals to gain the power they seek. After negotiations are done players reveal their choices simultaneously. This is often accompanied by a fanfare of cheers, laughs, and cries of anguish from the betrayed.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Humor, Negotiation, Political
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Jinmenbana: Chochorina Saibai Keikaku! (人面花 – チョチョリーナ栽培計画！)
description:
User summary
人面花 - チョチョリーナ栽培計画！ (Jinmenbana - Chochorina Saibai Keikaku!) in English is "Human Flower - Chochorina Cultivation Project!".

Chochorina Saibai Keikaku! is a card game with a theme of growing jinmenbana (a flower with human-looking face) called "Chochorina".

To raise the flower, players take turns playing cards, which are either fertilizer (positive growth) or pesticide (negative growth). The active player wins the game when total growth level is exactly seven, but if the flower has been overgrown (more than seven), that player is eaten by the flower and is out of the game, and the next player will be also eliminated unless the growth level is decreased to seven or less.

There are some event cards which make the game complicated and fun.

Two modes of the game are published at the same time. Red Box, where players raise a flower, is for novice gamers. Green Box, where players raise a cactus, is for intermediate gamers.

Publisher's summary
農家となり、人面花である「チョチョリーナ」を咲かせることを目指します。肥料や農薬を使って数値を上げ下げし、「7」ぴったりにした人が勝者です。「7」を越えると農家の方が食べられて敗けです！

name: Small Planets
description:
In Small Planets players take the roll of burnt-out writers which embark on a journey to the distant galaxy in search of inspiration. Planets are unusual: each of them has a distinct theme: western, industrial era etc. Players will send probes, which help them witness amazing things and events. The "richest" player wins the game.

At the beginning of the round players put a counter on each of six planets. Then, active player rolls three dice and puts additional counters on the corresponding planets. Then, players roll their dice and decide which to reroll. After that, active player asks players which planet they want to visit. Players then decide if they put the dice on the planet or not. Player who puts the most dice on the planet takes the counters from them and also gains a favor of planet's inhabitants. When all planets were pointed at by active player, the round ends. Players gather their dice and the next round begins. Game lasts 9 rounds. Player with the most counters at the end of the game wins.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Nine Planets
description:
User summary
Nine Planets is a butting game with a science fiction backdrop. 'Butting' is a term used in JP games when more than one player makes the same choice. The action might fall to the next player down, or the players might resolve the demand some way, such as bartering.

Each term consists of purchasing cards to construct your score base whilst reading your opponents and agonizing over different dilemmas.

Players receive points based on the planets to which they are able to successfully warp. If multiple warps to the same planet occur (multiple players choose the same planet), you will not be able to reach your intended destination. However, this does not necessarily mean you will land on a harmful planet (a planet with a negative effect).

Nine Planets is a game for people with the one or more the following characteristics:
People who like to analyze the current state of the board and make predictions about other players’ behaviour.
People who like games that require players to adapt quickly to each change. (A game where the situation changes every turn.)
People who enjoy the thrill of high risk and high return conditions.

''Publisher's summary
SFを舞台にしたバッティングゲームです。毎ターン、読み合いとジレンマに悩みながら、カードを購入して得点基盤を構築していきます。このゲームのポイントはどの惑星にワープするかですが、ワープが重なる（選択が被る）と、目的に惑星にはたどり着けません。しかし、それが悪い惑星（マイナスの効果）とも限りません。
ナインプラネッツはこんな人に向いています。「盤面の状況を読んでプレイヤーの行動を予測することが好きな人」「臨機応変な対応が求められるゲームが好きな人（毎ターン状況が変わる）」「ハイリスク・ハイリターンにワクワクする人」「一発逆転が少ないゲームが好きな人」
categories: Card Game, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Atropos
description:
Atropos is a mathematical (topological) game based on Sperner's lemma. No mathematical background is necessary in order to play the game. The game starts with a triangulation of a big triangle, whose three nodes are colored (say) red, yellow and green. Players take turns and color one vertex of the triangulation in red, yellow or green. There are two restrictions: (1) whenever possible, each player should color an adjacent vertex of the last-played vertex; (2) when coloring a vertex on an edge of the big triangle, only the two colors of its endpoints may be used, not the color of the opposing vertex.

Sperner's lemma guarantees that the game cannot end in a tie: when all vertices of a triangulation have been legally colored, there will always exist a small tricolored triangle (in fact, an odd number of them).

The mathematical complexity game has been studied and found to be PSPACE-complete in 2010 for the special case of a "regular" triangulation. In general, the game can be played with arbitrary triangulations, and with or without the rule that next moves must be adjacent to the last move.

name: Cricket With Dice
description:
•Number of players that can play this game is 2-8 players.
•Players are divided into two even teams.
•Each team would have one captain.
•Captains of both team would roll the dice, the player with the highest number gets to choose (ie) either Batting or Bowling.
•One Over consists of 6 chances before the turn ends.
•Each player of the team gets two strikes.
•Bowler gets 2 dice, Batsman gets 2 dice and Fielders get 1 die.
•Bowling team can choose any 1 fielder to be a part of the match.
•Batsman, Bowler and Fielder Roll the Dice.

HOW TO WIN:
•Team that beats the highest score before overs end or without losing their players wins.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Beano: Get Home Safe
description:
Appearing as an insert board game in a special safety issue of The Beano for Brake.

This is a simple roll-and-move game that also teaches some bike safety rules. The object is to bike home safely.

name: Autkiem przez kraj
description:
Easy, fast and very funny mini-game board brilliant for whole family. It is dedicated for one person and more - limited only by the place on the board. You have to play against the game's mechanism holding very simple rules.

In the box - you will find a simple colored board with drawing looped route.
Throw a dice and use cars (represented by pawns) to move them as long/far as you can. At the beginning yours cars have a pool of point, but the longer you go, yours cars wears out itself (losing points).
Every lap, you get extra points for necessary repairing. When you lose all your points, it means for you - game over. So, you have to care about your car.
There are a few fields with surprises on the route. Good and bad for your own or your opponent's cars

So, the question is: how far you will drive? Have a fun.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Humor, Racing, Travel
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Katra Mpantsaka
description:
Katra Mpantsaka (mpantsaka from tsaka "limited") is a mancala game played by the Sakalava people, which occupy the Western edge of the Madagascar from Toliara in the south to Sambirano in the north.

The game is typically played on a 4x8 board with 2 seeds in each hole, but it has also been described on 4x4 and 4x6 boards and with 3 seeds in each hole.

On his turn a player takes the contents of one of his holes and distributes them, one by one, either clockwise or counterclockwise into consecutive holes around the two rows of his own side. (For the remainder of the turn the direction of sowing may not be changed during a turn).

If the last stone falls into a non-empty hole, its contents are distributed in another lap continuing in the same direction as before.

The first lap must be started with an occupied hole of the inner row unless the inner row is empty. When the inner row is empty, a player may start from the back row. Unlike many other manacala games a move may start with a singleton.

The move ends when the last stone is dropped into an empty hole (mandri "to sleep"). However, if the last piece is placed in the inner row, then it captures the opponent's pieces on the inner row and the sowing continues play continues is if the last stone had landed in an non-empty row.

The game ends, when a player has no seeds left.

The player who captured all of the seeds, wins the game. The loser is said to be "lazy (kamo).

name: Healing Blade: Defenders of Soma – Kickstarter Exclusive Promo Cards
description:
These promo were sent to Kickstarter backers.

Allergic Villager
Provoker Card

If this villager is defended, respawn a new healthy villager and remove this from the game.

CANNOT be defended by cures listed: Carbapenem, Penicillin, Cephalosporin, B-Lactamase Inhibitor, Black Sigil

Pregnancy
Villager Card

During a planning phase, if there are at least 2 wounded, any player may replace a wounded female with this card. If successfully defended, remove this card from the game and reset the zone with a new healthy villager.

Cannot be defended by: Tetracycline, Black Sigil
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Medical

name: Swordpoint: Dark Age Armies
description:
Army list book containing 48 armies with additional variants, covering the period from 300 AD to 1066 AD. Army lists include:

Franks - 300
Mayan - 300
Dark Age Britain and Ireland - 300
Korean - 313
Huns - 350
Late Roman - 350
Gothic & Vandal Kingdoms - 442
Hindu Indian - 450
Early Byzantine - 475
Slav - 520
Champa - 550
Avars - 557
Khazar - 568
Heraclian Byzantine - 612
Tang China - 618
Tibetan - 620
Arab Conquest - 632
Bulgar - 643
Magyar - 650
Ethiopian - 650
Thematic Byzantine - 660
Christian Spanish - 711
Vikings - 750
Rus - 750
Arab Caliphates - 750
Al Andalus and Granada - 755
Carolingian - 768
Japanese - 794
Later Saxon Kingdoms - 800
Early Medieval Wales - 800
Khmer Empire - 802
Later Irish - 830
Burmese - 849
Pecheneg - 850
Khitan Empire - 907
Norman and Breton - 911
Seljuk Turks - 950
Song Chinese - 960
Ghaznavid - 960
Early Polish - 966
Georgian - 975
Turcoman - 971
Capetian France - 987
Early Medieval Hungarian - 1000
Anglo Danish - 1016
North African Berbers - 1042
Later Byzantine - 1042
Early Italian City States - 1050
Cuman or Kipchak - 1054

name: Campionato d'Italiano
description:
Italian language and trivia board game by Eli.

Test your knowledge of the language with this game, widening the cultural background through questions about culture, civilization, traditions, geography, sayings, environment and leisure.

Source: Publisher Site
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Austerlitz
description: Austerlitz is an operational game of the campaign in Austria during November and December 1805. The time scale is four turns per day (for a total of 92). The map scale is not stated, but it appears to be about 4km per hex. The board comes on eight 8.5 x 14 inch sheets that must be trimmed and joined together. The 182 counters must be mounted and cut. In addition to standard movement and combat, the rules cover supply, morale, commanders, bridges, and fortifications. Step losses are tracked on Casualty Charts for each side.

name: Cosmoclasm
description:
The fate of the solar system is at stake as several cosmic factions struggle for supremacy. As a commander of a star fleet, it is your duty to position your forces at the right time at the right planet and claim it for your faction. Beware, the strongest faction will claim the entire planet and there is no space for runners-up in the solar system.

The solar system consists of 12 planets, each of them surrounded by six grid points where battle stations may be placed. Some grid points border several planets, hence making their battle stations more powerful. You claim a planet if you have the most battle stations at the end of a round. You win if you claim 3/4/5 planets (5/4/3 players).

Each round you compete for the next planet in order. You do so by playing cards representing either two forces (black) or one force (white). One black card may be played each turn together with none or one white card. The black cards must follow suit while the white cards may be played together with any suit.

When you pass you take the tricks of all forces with a majority and places one battle station for each trick. Also, an early pass gives you an early pick of new cards from a drawing row. However, it makes the remaining tricks easier to get for the other players.

When the round ends, you claim the planet if you have the most battle stations around it. Also, any previous planets that were tied in previous rounds are reassessed to see if the majority has changed. (Remember that a battle station may reach more planets.) One of the tricks allows you to change the order of the planets to take advantage of well positioned battle stations.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Network and Route Building, Trick-taking

name: The Nebula From Hell: First Expansion
description: The First Expansion adds tons of new cards that change up the pace, add new challenges, and deliver a whole new amount of pain to an already hard game.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Zeppelin
description:
Winner of the 8th Board Game Design Competition Ciutat de Granollers (2015).

Players move their zeppelins across the board by using their turn actions; they move them, increase or decrease its flight altitude and try to make the most of the events that are being placed on the board. They also use special events against their opponents. The object is to get the 5 mission cards in the desired order.

A player, by spending an action, can place a normal event -Volcano,Festival or Wind- on an allowed terrain section. Normal events, once thrown, remain on the board.A player can link winds.

Special events are mixed with the rest of the events and they also cost an action. All special events are discarded after being used.

The player who manages to land on the fifth missions spending the lesser number of actions will be the winner.

French:
Pilotez un zeppelin à travers le plateau! Utilisez de façon intelligente dans votre propre intérêt et/ou contre autres joueurs des éruptions volcaniques et des vents enchaînables et amusants afin de modifier les routes et être le premier à achever les missions.

Équilibre entre stratégie et amusement. On a l’impression de jouer en 3 dimensions. La difficulté de chercher les routes optimales augmente à fur et à mesure que la partie avance. De l’haute interaction parmi les joueurs qui utilisent événements pour modifier le plateau.

Les zeppelins se déplacent, à tour de rôle, sur un plateau qui, à cause des décisions des joueurs, devient de plus en plus compliqué. L’un des joueurs gagne de manière serrée.

name: Candidate Land
description:
Deck building game about the race to the White House.
Players take on the role of running a campaign to make your candidate the next president of the USA. Each party will recruit strategies to secure states and earn electoral votes.

Candidate Land is a 2 player Deck building game (3-4 player with the expansion). Using the actual Electoral votes as victory points, this is a fresh look at political games. If you are a fan of deck building or political games, this is right up your alley! With over 220 cards, this is the first of its kind and has created many fans of deck building and political games!

Can you outwit, out-strategize, out-slander the other Candidates and become the Next President of the United States?

name: Legends of Four Kingdoms
description:
Legends of the Four Kingdoms is a captivating strategy game. Nature, technology, power, magic! Learn how to tame the Four Kingdoms.

Designed to be played with 2-8 players, you will only need one 40 card deck to play the game.

HOW TO PLAY

Each player is dealt three cards.

Cards in your hand represent the warriors you have control over. After dealing 3 cards to each player, the next card is dealt face up on the playing surface, and the remaining deck is placed face down. This card is the leading/crown Kingdom, and represents the trump suit for the game.

Play one card each going clockwise, player to the left of the dealer starts. After playing a card, draw one more card from the face down pile.

Winning a hand:

In ascending order: fewest to most soldiers (they are worth 0 points) then the following: Knight (J) with 2 points; War Princess (Q) with 3 points; King (K) with 4; Supreme Warrior (3*) with 10; and the Kingdom's secret weapon worth 11 points.

If any Leading/Crown Kingdom (trump) has been played, the player who played the highest valued trump wins. If no Leading/Crown Kingdom (trumps) have been played, the player who played the highest card of the lead suit wins.

Players are not required to follow suit.

Once the winner of a round is determined, that player collects the played cards, and places them face down in a pile. Each player maintains his/her own pile. Then, each player draws a card from the remaining deck, starting with the player who won the trick, proceeding counter-clockwise. The player who won the round leads the next hand.

The winner is the player who won the most important battles and has the most points. There are 120 points total.

Legends of the Four Kingdoms reimplements the traditional Italian trick-taking game Briscola, with modern artwork and new suits.

name: Napoleon and his Marshals: The Peninsular War
description:
The first addition to Napoleon and his Marshals expands the series to include the wars in Spain and Portugal from 1805-1815, with scenarios for 1807-1814 and 1809-1814. The basic set (Napoleon and his Marshals) is required to play. The complete British army and navy for the basic game is added, along with the Spanish army and navy and the Portuguese army. A 20.75 x 16 inch map of Spain, Portugal, Southern France and the adjacent seas is included along with two 88-counter sheets of 0.6" square game counters, printed front and back. Scale is approximately 38 miles per hex.

Like its parent game, this is a diceless combat system, based on our algorithm for battles in that period. The gameplay is identical to that of Napoleon and his Marshals, with some minor modifications for the scenarios.

Rules are the same as for Napoleon and his Marshals.

name: Kechi
description: Kechi is an abstract strategy game played with black and white stones on a 13x13 grid. On each turn, a player moves his stones a toral of six cells. Each stone must finish its move on an available empty space or one occupied by an enemy stone (which is then captured). The player who cannot make a move on his turn loses. When a stone leaves a space, that space is marked as unplayable. In this is resembles Hey, That's My Fish! or Amazons.

name: Kingdom
description: Kingdom is an abstract strategy game played on a 9x9 board with a King piece and stacks of 1-4 checkers called Knights. Pieces can move to an adjacent empty cell or jump over an adjacent piece. Knights may only jump over a Knight smaller than themselves, except a one-high Knight may jump over a four-high Knight. Pieces capture by moving into an enemy piece's space. Any piece may capture a King, and Kings may capture Knights, but Knights may not capture Knights (they only block each other). The player who captures the enemy king or occupies the enemy king's starting location wins.

name: Ariadne's Thread: Escape the Maze Button by Button!
description:
Each player starts with 5 buttons.When it’s your turn, place a button on the thread if you have one that is the same colour, shape or size, as the last button and one oh the adjacent buttons, when you reach the buttonholes with arrows. If you manage to place a button, then you draw a new one from the bag; otherwise you have to discard one.
Extra buttons can be won during the game as prizes.
The winner is the player who gets out of the maze with the most buttons!
Younger players can play Tower, a game that helps them learn colours and recognize shapes and sizes through touch.

name: Snakes
description:
SNAKES - Make the most snakes to win!


COMPONENTS:
16 wooden dice: 12 with green snakes, 4 with orange snakes
1 instruction sheet

INSTRUCTIONS:

GOAL
Complete more snakes than your opponent.
PREPARATION
Each player gets 8 dice: 6 green and 2 orange. The youngest player starts by throwing a green die and placing it on the playing surface. This will be the start of the first snake.
TURNS
Each player takes a turn to throw one of their dice and line it up with the part of the snake already on the playing area, thus continuing to create the snake and, hopefully, completing it. A snake is complete when it has a head and a tail. A snake only needs to have two pieces - a head and a tail - to be complete. For each completed snake, the player who placed the final piece earns 1 point. Once a snake has been completed, it is left on the playing area. If you cannot attach the section of the snake obtained from throwing one of your dice, then start a new snake. If there is more than one unfinished snake on the playing area, then the person whose turn it is can decide which snake to continue or complete. After each player has had one turn, it is possible to throw one of the orange dice at any time during the game. If this orange die ends up on one of the standard “head” or “tail” faces, then the rules are exactly the same as for the green dice. If the orange die ends up on a "+", you can take one die (including another orange one, if one is already on the playing area) from the end of a snake in the playing area; you also get to keep the orange die and get to throw again, using the die of your choice, straightaway. If the die that is taken from a snake is removed from a completed snake, then person who originally won a point for completing that snake keeps the point. If the orange die ends up on, you have to give your orange die to the other player and forfeit your turn.

END OF GAME

Every time you complete a snake, you get 1 point. The game ends when all the pieces have been used. The winner is the player with the most points, i.e. the person who completed the most snakes.

name: The Colour Towers
description:
BUILD THE HIGHEST TOWER EVER!

The Colour Towers is a wooden board game based on the colour theory! It is an educational game for children and for the whole family. It is also an unusual gift.

COMPONENTS: 34 pawns made of 100% beechwood (100% FSC®) in 6 colours, 1 bag, 1 brochure containing the instructions and the explanation of the colour theory.
INSTRUCTIONS:

Pick a pawn from the bag. There are three ways to conquer the pawns on the field or on top of towers of the other players: 1. Easy: you conquer the pawns of the SAME COLOUR as the one you picked from the bag (example: if you pick a red pawn you can conquer a red pawn) if there is any free on the field or on the top of the towers of the other players. 2. Average: you can conquer pawns according to the SUM OF COLOURS, meaning that you can conquer pawns of the colours that when mixed together make the colour of the pawn you picked (example: a violet pawn can conquer red and blue pawns). 3. Advanced: you can get the pawns of the COMPLEMENTARY COLOUR of the pawn you picked. If you cannot conquer any pawn, leave the picked pawn on the field. The conquered pawns are to be piled up to form a tower. The player who build the highest tower wins the game. In the package you will find the COMPLETE INSTRUCTIONS AND THE COLOUR THEORY

name: T-Boats Challenge
description:
T - Boats Challenge
NEW BATTLESHIP!

It is a wooden board game for all ages based on strategy: there is no luck, only tactics!


COMPONENTS: 1 wooden game board, 8 wooden ship-pawns in 2 colours


INSTRUCTIONS:

Goal: Eliminate all the rival sheeps from the board.
Preparation: Arrange all the ships on the board on the starting position (1). Pick the colours. The yellow fleet always starts.

How to move the ships: The game board is composed by 81 spots. One ship must always fill three spots. Play in turns. The player shall move one ship making a 90° rotation in any direction pivoting on one of the three spots filled by the ship or shift it of one spot lengthways. (2) The ship can only fill free spots without crossing other ships. It is allowed to pass over a ship if the ending spots are free. (3) If the player touches a ship is obliged to make a move.
How to eliminate the rival ships: The goal of your moves is to build a "T" across one enemy ship by placing one ship perpendiculalry and centerd to the rival one building a "T" (4). In this way the rival ship must be taken from the board. If you build a "T" unintentionally and don't see it, the other player is allowed not to tell and to eliminate your ship at the next turn without making any other move. If with one move you manage to make more "Ts" you can remove all the involved ships.
End of the game: If a player can eliminate all the rival ships or prevent them from moving further, he wins the game. If a player gives up the other one wins. The game shall be considered even is both players cannot move further.

name: Forgotten Battles: Scenarios for WWII Spearhead Rules
description:
Subtitled 'Scenarios for Spearhead WW-II Rules', these additional scenarios cover the Eastern Front.

Although designed primarily for Spearhead rules, these scenarios are playable with any set of WW-II rules that provides Divisional organizations and uses the Platoon as the smallest combat element.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Sultans of Wind: Relics of Power
description:
Sultans of Wind: Relics of Power adds twelve new cloud tiles to the Sultans of Wind base game. Some of these tiles have pillars on them, with a relic being placed randomly atop each pillar for players to grab during play. Players can typically use these relics to attack or block one another.

Sultans of Wind: Relics of Power also includes new gameplay modes.

name: Brutus: The Board Game
description:
In the 2000s, each player is one of the VIPs of Small City. Each one hides behind a pseudonym of a Roman emperor, based on the special ability that player chose at the beginning of the game. The goal of Brutus: The Board Game is to racketeer the commerces, to rob the residences, and to hire new thugs in the industries. Each turn, you move your Roman empire figure, and can either destroy or burgle a building. Thus you gain more and more influence in the districts. The player who builds up the most influence in Small City wins.

The city is represented on a hex hex grid, and its size depends on the number of players.

There are two ways to play this game in the Small City universe. A book should be included in the box, a hard-boiled novel that deals with the story of the same six emperors, which takes place after the story of the board game. A new concept to expand the board game...
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Math+Op
description:
Math+Op is a card game based on math problem solving together. Each players have number cards. Players choose a rulesmaker at first. Each person get one card from number card deck. Player who gets big number is rulesmaker. Rulesmaker gives ten card at a time face down, beginning with the player on the right. Each player gets 10 cards but rulesmaker 11 cards. The remaining number cards and operations cards are placed face down separately on the table, forming the stock.

Rulesmaker placed at first number card. Player at right of rulesmaker gets number or operation card from stock and placed. Player who placed result number card is winner.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Math, Memory, Number
mechanics: Acting, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Memory

name: Larger Than Life: The Director's Cut – Action! A Scenario Book
description:
Description from the book:

In Larger Than Life – Directors Cut you learned that it all boils down to the Story and we gave you the tools to create them.

In Action we’ve taken it a step farther; now we’ve given you three full blown adventures. Each Story comes complete with pre-generated Stars, Co-Stars, Big Bads, and more, but they will work just as well with your own cast.

STORY #1 – You’re “Duke” Clayton, world traveling adventurer, and you’re girlfriend Leilani, has been kidnapped by a power crazed villain – and what about Hooni, the Great Squid God?

STORY #2 – You’re the Gray Raven – a Vigilante whose current case involves stolen artifacts and murders – not one, but many. You’ll be required to bring your best as you travel south to a Hidden Valley deep in the Peruvian jungle.

STORY #3 – It’s Germany 1935 and there’s been a scientist kidnapped. In our 3rd adventure we’ve given you a classic pre-World War II spy story, but with a couple of twists.
categories: Adventure, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Miniatures, Murder/Mystery, Mythology, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Storytelling, Variable Player Powers

name: Fussballspiel Fortuna
description:
Each player has 10 field players and one goalie. Movement is determined by a die. The direction may be changed once during movement. If a player gets on the same space as the ball he gets an extra move for the ball. The ball can't change direction during movement. The ball may move through occupied spaces. If the movement of the ball ends not on the space of a friendly field player, the opponent gets his turn. If the movement of the ball ends on one of the three numbered spaces in front of the goal, the goalie catches the ball, if he rolls one of the numbers shown on the space the ball is in.

After an agreed on playing time the player who gets the most goals wins the game.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Diabolical Dungeons
description:
This is a fantasy card game in which players each take on the role of a fantasy adventurer (cleric, ranger, rogue, warrior, or wizard) who starts the game with a randomly selected personality trait, personal motivation, and end goal.

All adventurers are part of a party, and they work cooperatively to reach the Lair Card (where the chosen adventure's Boss Monster is revealed). If the party defeats the boss, they win, and gain an Epic Treasure Card. Otherwise, they die and lose the game.

The objective of the Solo version of the game is to accomplish your character's End Goal before s/he becomes too cowardly, despairing, mad, reviled, or too dead to continue adventuring.

Different End Goals include: Becoming Accomplished (in a certain discipline or skill), becoming Powerful, being Revered as a god, becoming Renowned (for performing feats), or by attaining great Wealth.

To accomplish the End Goal, the adventurer travels from Location Card to Location Card.

When the adventurer enters a Location, s/he can do one of four things: Make Camp (to hunt and rest), Interact with the displayed NPC, do Trade (rolling on a table), or Explore the Location.

To explore, the Location Card is flipped over, revealing an Encounter. Encounters represent monsters, traps, or perilous situations that must be defeated. Successfully defeating these encounters results in gaining XP and Treasure Cards.
