categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Political

name: Ortus Regni: Welsh Marshes
description:
2-6 player, Ortus Regni variant mat.

The border of the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and Wales is a wild frontier, neither English nor Welsh. Marcher lords rule fiefdoms that thrive in this no-man’s land between two civilizations; where the ancient Britannic people of Wales live as uneasy neighbors of the more recent Germanic Anglo-Saxon conquerors and settlers of Britain.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Political

name: Ortus Regni: High Marshall
description:
2-6 player, Ortus Regni variant mat.

The offices of the Shires are the start of a more formal secular organization in the early kingdoms of England. Evolving slowing, but surely, from ancient traditional Anglo-Saxon tribal leadership organization into the great royal and bureaucratic titles that we recognize today.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Political

name: Ortus Regni: Knight-Errant
description:
A unique way to play Ortus Regni; variantmat for 2-4 players.

You are Knights of the Realm, not great Earls. But you hope to rise in stature by having that title bestowed on you and your house.

Earning the respect of the great peers of the Realm, catching their eye with your strength and guile, will secure your rise.
A Knight wins Knight-errant instantly when they possess any 3 of the unique victory conditions; as mere Knights would dare not touch the person or possessions of a recognized Earl. Status is everything in this world, and all the other great Earls of the land would immediately crush such a challenge to the hierarchy!
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Political

name: Floods Krigsspel
description:
Strategic wargame with a game board showing a map of most of Europe with a square grid overlaid. Playing pieces are steel miniatures of different types of military units. Rules are included for three types of games. The first type of game is played with infantry units only and movement controlled by rolling dice. It is intended for younger players. The second type also uses only infantry, but with deterministic chess-like moves and no dice. The third type adds all the other types of units. The goal in all games is to capture the flag in the enemy capital or reduce the enemy army to less than half of the own army's size.

Included in the game are miniature armies for Germany and France allowing for a two-player game on a war between those two nations fought on land only. Expansion armies for 15 other European countries were sold separately as well as expansions adding navies for 12 of the nations.

The rules recommend playing with one player per major country, but that two players play Germany as a team if fighting a two-front war against both France and Russia.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Frozen: The Ball at Arendelle
description:
Description from the publisher:

Frozen: The Ball at Arendelle is a board game for children based on the popular Disney cartoon Frozen. The game is an interesting and colorful memory trainer — the players have to figure out who didn't come to the ball. Everything happens in a very simple way.

At the beginning players are looking at the 6 chips for five second and trying to remember them. Then chips turn around and shuffled. Only 5 chips are opened after that and players have to say what character on the 6th chip. Guessed player take the snowflake and the winner is the first one who get 10 snowflakes.

name: Kickin' Your Ass!
description:
Kickin’ Your Ass is a set collection / take that card game where you try to build your Ass, while kicking other players’ Asses.
You try to collect each piece of Ass you can get your hands on. Once you have enough Ass to complete your Ass, you win. But along the way, other players are trying to kick your Ass. This of course results in you losing your Ass, or at least some of it.

Each player starts with a hand of four cards.  All cards are drawn from a common deck.  You build your Ass out of 5 cards, Tail, Back Legs, Middle, Front Legs, Head.
All the while, you play cards to Kick someone’s Ass which makes them lose pieces of their Ass. You can try to stop this by playing Get Off My Ass cards.

If you can find your ass with both hands, you can play Kickin' Your Ass!

(from publisher)

name: Sum2Zero
description:
SUM2ZERO is the innovative card game that puts a spin on zero-sum game theory.

Easy to Play
Each player starts with 10 cards. The object of the game is to place 1 to 3 cards, so that your cards plus the base card add to zero. The first player with no cards wins the game.

Red cards are negative numbers from -1 to -12 while black cards are positive numbers from +1 to +12. Action cards – Boom!, Reset, Checked, Imaginary, Thunder, and Cubit - have been added to give it a twist!

What’s in the Box
104 total cards
- 44 positive number (1 to 12) cards
- 44 negative number (-1 to -12) cards
- 3 positive and 3 negative imaginary cards
- 2 Boom!, 2 Reset, 2 Checked, 2 Thunder, and 2 Cubit cards

Examples:

If the base card is positive 7, a player could throw a negative 7 card.
(+7) + (-7) = 0

If the base card is positive 7, a player could throw a negative 1, negative 2, and negative 4 cards.
(+7) + (-1) + (-2) + (-4) = 0

If the base card is positive 7, a player could throw a positive 8, negative 10, and negative 5 cards.
(+7) + (+8) + (-10) + (-5) = 0

If the base card is positive 7, a player could throw a negative imaginary card (choose the card to be -11) and a positive 4.
(+7) + (-i) + (+4)= 0

name: Chronomega
description:
The year is 2137. The crew and equipment of the Time-Space Research Station, Chronomega One, have been emergency-ejected into outer space. You play one of the surviving scientists who must collect pieces of floating research tech and combine them into Electromagnetic-, Gravity-, and Time-bending tools to help bring Chronomega One back under control. You have no idea which member of the crew is responsible for the emergency protocol lock-down and crew ejection, so you can’t trust any of them!

The player's goal is to collect a full set of the three types of Computer cards (all values 1, 2, 3) to unlock the Station Key Code, and reach the central Computer portal of the station first (and in advanced play, before the station explodes).

The game utilizes a rotating space station board and transparent hexagonal tech cards that represent the four 'suits' of the game, Electromag, Gravity, Chrono, and Computer. The players get three actions each turn to move about the board or play cards. They'll want to collect the floating tech cards during their turn and utilize them for different effects. All the tech cards consist of one of the four suits and are valued 1-3.

If a player encounters another player on the board, they'll utilize their tech cards to engage in a showdown. This consists of each player bidding one of their tech cards. The bids are then revealed and winner determined based on the tech suit played. Certain types of tech defeat others: Electro defeats Grav, Grav defeats Chrono, Chrono defeats Electro. If two types of the same suit are played, higher values defeat lower. All suits defeat Computer, unless their values match (e.g. Grav 3 vs Computer 3), in which case the Computer suit player wins. The winner takes the card that was bid and may push the opposing player 3 spaces (if in outer space), or up or down one level of the space station (including out into an airlock).

All tech cards have a basic function they may be played for as an action, such as move an extra space or to force another player to discard cards. Two transparent tech cards also may be combined and over-layed to activate a catalytic effect, which grants different powers based on the combined card's values and suits. If a full three-part set of tech cards are collected of the same suit (values 1, 2, and 3 of a single suit) they form a POD. These grant the most significant abilities in the game. The more powerful card effects require the player to be standing upon an appropriate research portal to use, either one of the permanent portals within the rotating space station or from a floating portal out in space that they cobbled together from another high-value tech card of the same suit.

The space station itself is surrounded by trapped airlocks which make simply entering the station a risky endeavor. While inside, every time a player ends a turn within the space station their ring level rotates 90 degrees, lining up different portals and pathways with the inter-level Grav chutes. Furthermore, other players may cobble together Electro catalyzers from floating tech cards to try and teleport players into other areas of the station, spend Grav tech to pull cards away from other players, or utilize Chrono tech cards to cause the addition or loss of turns and actions.

Once a player with a full hand of Computer cards reaches the inner Computer Portal of the station, they deactivate Chronomega One’s self-destruct sequence and win the game.
mechanics: Action Points, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Family Business: Kingpins of Crime promo expansion
description:
As your mob grows smaller, each of your mobsters get a bigger slice of the pie. With that ability comes some extra perks.

This promo is a two-page rules variant for Family Business published in Game Trade Magazine (Issue 188 - Oct 2015) as "Mayfair Games' Limited Edition Promo Expansion Set #22".
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Mafia
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Take That

name: Atticus Scroll: Journey of the Pharaoh
description:
In 1837, British Egyptologist, John Atticus discovers a clay jar in the Egyptian desert. When he opens the jar, he finds an ancient scroll written in hieroglyphs. He translates the scroll which contains the one true way for a Pharaoh to navigate from this world to the afterlife. It was the Journey of the Pharaoh.

Object of the Game
You are the designated Vizier and must help your Pharaoh navigate successfully the journey from this world to the afterlife. Beware of the many challenges and pitfalls that may impede your Pharaoh’s path. Acquire amulets along the way for protection and avoid the deadly clutches of the Ammit.

As players progress around the game board, they will pass the Scarab Sun. Once a player passes the Scarab Sun, he/she should take a card and follow the instructions of the card. If a player retreats or trades places with another, then do not draw a card. Replace the card on the bottom of the deck when done.

Each icon on the game board has an associated action to it.

To win the game, a player must roll the die and advance the exact number of spaces needed to reach the Ra (sun) symbol. If the exact number is not rolled, then the player stays in the same position.

name: Tapaono
description:
The objective of this strategy game is to have conquered more fields than the opponent at the end of the game. Various game modes (victory conditions) are available. Played on a play area with 151 hexagonal squares, of which 139 can be conquered. Each player receives three tokens and 100 field marks. The game is turn-based. Each turn consists of the following four phases:
1. Move 2. Draw commands-cards 3. Capture by rolling 4. Capture by commands,
which are always played in this order.
When a player has completed his turn, the second player has his turn. This is repeated until one of the players has won the game mode determined by both players at the beginning.
The player has to move each of his token one field every turn. He rooling the dice for each token and destinkt so how many fields he can conquer surround his token. If the player roll a five he can conquer or free five fields.
The player conquer free fields or free conquered fields. If a field with a token is conquerd, the token go back to the spawn.
Each time a player move on one of the 12 fields with a star (wich can not be conquerd) he has to draw a command-card.
With this command-cards he can supply for example his movement, instead of one movement turn per token he has by playing the command "move +1" two turns for one token. The command-cards are very different. Some have supply effects for the movement other supply the conquering and others are traps with negative effects. Some of the command-cards ask the player to roll the dice. For example how many fields a player lose by drawing a trap-card.
Some commands (max 5)can be collected in the "depot" and played as a chain.

There is also an assist app available in Google Playstore

name: Fleeting Glory
description: Fleeting Glory allows one to conduct abstracted battles in the Napoleonic era. Hidden information and a chit pull system effectively allow solitaire or head to head play. The game takes its inspiration from Napoleon's Triumph, Battles of Napoleon, Stratego etc. and spits out a rules foot print of less than 10 pages. Play time permits multiple engagements in a single afternoon. Experience a marriage of skill and chance that enables one to build tactical puzzles similar to those the commanders of old faced.

name: 6-Tage-Rennen
description:
Each player has 2 bicycles. Movement is determined by one die. The players start at the colored spaces (Spitzengruppe) in the center of the game board. The game consists of 6 racing days á 2 spurts. Each spurt consists of one lap around the track by one bicycle. Points are awarded for each spurt. Players who get outstripped change from "Spitzengruppe" to "1 Runde zurück" and so on.
Winner is the player in "Spitzengruppe" who gets the most points.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hasch' mich auf der Autobahn
description:
Each player gets 1 car. Movement is determined by a standard die (1-6) and a color die (red, blue, green). The color die indicates the direction of movement at the crossroads (red = left, blue = right, green = any). If movement starts in a city, any direction can be chosen. There are 5 different kinds of play:

1) Hasch' mich auf ter Autobahn: The players start in the center space (Berlin) and try to catch one another. The last player on the board wins the game.

2) Fuchsjagd: One player (Fox) is hunted by all the other players. The fox has to reach all cities marked with "F" to win the game. Any player who catches the fox has to assume the role of the fox, while the former fox is eliminated from the game. The last hunter wins the game, if he catches the fox before he has reached all his destinations.

3) Sternfahrt: The players start from a city marked with "St". The first player to reach the center space (Berlin) wins the game.

4) Streckenrekord: The players starr from Berlin and try to get as far from there as possible. Each player who returns to Berlin is eliminated from the game. The last player on the board wins the game.

5)Grenzfahrt: The players start in a city marked with "G" and have to travel to all other cities marked with "G". The first player to achieve this and returns to his starting city wins the game.

The game was published between 1936 and 1945.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Wisdomantics
description:
From the box
"Wisdomantics - Where Wisdom is Power is an interactive DVD board game for players of various faiths who desire to gain the vast wisdom of King Solomon. Wisdomantics utilizes the proverbs of Solomon to and blends chance, knowledge and strategy to create a fun experience while you learn."

Wisdomantics is a Biblical trivia game with track movement and set collection. Players attempt to complete Solomon's Temple by answering trivia questions about the proverbs of Solomon (included on a DVD) and then choosing a card that allows them to move around a track. As they move, they collect building materials (Gold, Cedar and Cypress) that they use to complete Solomon's Temple on their player board. Players also collect blessing cards. Blessing cards or building materials may be trades 3-for-1 for other resources. The first player to complete his or her temple wins.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Jetta D-1: World Travel Game
description:
Jetta D-1 World Travel Game is designed to teach geography.
"Jetta" is a contraction of JET Travel Adventure. In this game, each player chooses a travel itinerary that will take them around the world in a series of flights and places their airplane pawn on the world map board. They then roll two dice repeatedly and add the totals until they reach the exact total required to move their pawn to the next city in their itinerary. They record how many rolls it took. The rules do not specify what to do if the roll total goes over the exact amount needed. When each player has completed his or her itinerary, the player who rolled the dice the fewest times wins. Players will learn the names and locations of cities as well as airport codes.

name: Space Travel Game
description: Space Travel Game was a Jack in the Box kids' meal giveaway. It is a simple spin-and-move game packaged in a small plastic clamshell box. The top of the box is a spinner. Inside is a folded game board with a track leading a space shuttle back to Earth. Players spin and move their pieces either forward or backward on the track (or lose a turn) as indicated, trying to be the first to reach Earth. A note on game design: The spinner is exactly balanced between moving forward and moving backward, and with 40 spaces on the board, this could be a very long game.

name: Kickin' Your Ass!: The Drunk Edition
description:
Description from the publisher:

This is the more drunker edition of the ass grabbin’ Kickin’ Your Ass card game. It is a card game where you try to build your Ass, while kicking other players’ Asses and where getting your Ass kicked means shots!

You try to collect each piece of Ass you can get your hands on. Once you have enough Ass to complete your Ass, you win. But along the way, other players are trying to kick your Ass and force you to drink!. This of course results in you losing your Ass, or at least some of it.

Each player starts with a hand of four cards. All cards are drawn from a common deck. You build your Ass out of 5 cards, Tail, Back Legs, Middle, Front Legs, Head.

All the while, you play cards to Kick someone’s Ass which makes them lose pieces of their Ass and drink so it get’s better the more ass you kick.

There are also defensive cards such as Kiss My Ass that will prevent this and force the kicker to drink.

name: Kriegs-Spiel
description:
This is a two-player German war game published in about 1880. The playing board features a castle in the center surrounded by a two-layer multi-colored track running from 1-70. On each side is rectangular block of colored numbers, with 1-35 on one side and 36-70 on the other. There are illustrations of fighting in the four corners, with uniforms representing the then-recent Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71.

To start, the players each put an agreed amount into the pot to fund the war. They then take turns rolling a single die, and advancing that many spaces on their respective tracks. The first to reach space 70 wins the war and the pot.

The color of each space has an effect on play. If a player lands on a green space, the opponent must drop back to the nearest red space. A player who lands on a blue space must pay one mark to his opponent. Landing on a gold space means paying a mark into the pot, while landing on a lilac space grants another roll of the die.

The board consists of a sheet of paper pasted onto thick cardboard. A second game is pasted onto the reverse side.

name: Zuirius
description:
Zuirius is a strategic board game played on an endless triangular grid. It is possible to play on any flat surface, without the special board. The goal of the game is to block all tetrahedrons of your rival.

In this game there is no captures or direct confrontation of pieces. During the game the number of pieces is not changed, all tetrahedrons are interconnected and constantly depend on each other. The compact starting position of pieces passes through various irreversible metamorphoses and, having exhausted all its "energy", freezes as a result. You can play with 18, 24, 30, 36 or 42 pieces. The more pieces, the harder the game will be.

Rules:

Each player has an allocated color. Players alternate turns. All tetrahedrons must be connected in a single group. You cannot pick up a piece to move if doing so disconnects the remaining pieces, even if they would be reconnected after putting the piece into its new location. Each tetrahedron always has neighbors. Their number can be from 1 to 12. Tetrahedrons are considered to be neighbors if they stand on the nearby triangles. Neighbors are divided into two types - orthogonal and diagonal. The piece can be moved to any empty triangle, where the number of neighbors are less than it is now. Their color does not matter. The piece can also be moved to any empty triangle, where the number of neighbors does not change, but orthogonal ones among them become less. The game ends when one of the players has no legal moves on his turn. In this case, the winner does as many moves as he can and earns one point for each move. When both players lose moves consecutively it's a draw.

name: 1705: El desembarcament
description:
Card game based in the landing of Austriacist troops in Montgat (near Barcelona) in 1705, during the War of the Spanish Succession.

The aim of the players is to get 10 points, playing the best sets of cards. At the peginning of a game, each player gets a special permanent character, which gives some special power). Then from a draw pile, in each turn, a player draws a card and plays as many cards as he wants in his playing area, trying to play the best sets, to either get points or to destroy card sets already played by other players.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Story Dogs
description: Story Dogs (のせのせDOGS) is a card game.

name: Dice of Our Lives
description:
A Soap Opera themed board game where players interact with twelve characters (cast members) throughout the game. The players play themselves and all also considered cast members of the drama taking place in the town of Fine Valley. The goal of the game is to reach the Laun-Dramatic and disclose the 'ugly truth' of all the players. This is done by separating the truth from the 'vicious gossip' given by the twelve characters.

Similar to Clue, players must roll the dice to move their token towards places of their choosing. Once at a location, the player interacts with a character to get them to disclose a rumor about one of the other players.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Grossdeutschlands Stadtespiel
description:
This 1940 geographical word game was designed to teach Germans the names of cities within the boundaries of the recently expanded Third Reich.

The rules booklet includes the names of each major city together with a representative drawing, sometimes with a coat of arms or other symbol, and a short verse about the city. The game board features only the illustrations and symbols for each city, not the names. Players are encouraged to read the booklet before starting the game.

The stock of small red and black letter tiles is placed in a bag or opaque bowl, and players take turns drawing blind, one tile at a time until a red letter tile is drawn. The player drawing the red tile must place it as the initial letter of one of the cities. After that, the player may place as many black letters in his hand as possible that continue the spelling of any city name that has been started with a red letter.

Play then passes to the left. Each player in turn first draws another tile from the stock and then places as many letters as possible. If a player draws a red letter, he must place it immediately. If he is unable to identify a suitable city, he must place the letter in front of him, after which the first player to call "Halt" may take and play the letter, and then continue his turn. Play then passes left from the seizing player.

Players must continue to draw a letter at the beginning of each turn, even if they have no tiles left. The winner is the player who first uses up all his tiles after the last tile has been drawn from the stock.

The map board includes Vienna, Graz, Prague and the major cities of occupied Poland as German, but still shows Denmark as independent, meaning it was based on the borders as they stood between October 1939 and April 1940.
categories: Educational, Word Game, World War II

name: Dice Tracks
description:
Roll those dice and draw some tracks!

Your goal is to connect all cities and towns, by drawing your tracks in 13 turns.

You can upgrade cities and towns, gain new dice and take loans in this 15 minute game.

You need a printed out map, a pen/pencil, 6 10-sided dice and 2 markers (wooden cubes).

Will you be able expand your network in time?

name: Quizmania
description:
Description from the publisher:

Quizmania was created for all who like to have fun with friends and use time profitably! We turned the classic format of the game into quizzes not forgetting about technologies. This game gives you a chance to test your knowledge and compete with friends at home, outside or in your favorite cafe!

Purpose of the game

It’s very simple. The first team that answers correctly to the quizzes, solves 360 ​​VR tasks using smartphone and Google Cardboard and reaches the finish line wins!
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Conquerings
description:
Conquerings is a rapid action dexterity game featuring the patent pending Moveable Target mechanic.

The Moveable Target mechanic is the novel concept of strategy ring toss. It includes multiple peg boards where the pegs are spaced so that one ring has the potential of getting many pegs. In addition to a ring getting multiple pegs and a kingdom encompassing multiple peg boards there are also targets that can be placed on/around pegs and moved around to activate abilities for attacking and defending kingdoms.

This is a game full of genres. Players choose a Kingdom with associated Kingdom Boards. The Kingdoms are one of Pirates, Zombies, Knights, Pig Cyborgs, Angels or Fairies.(With expansions Yeti, Sorceress, Treants, Reptilians, Cowboys, Sirens)
Players decide if they wish to play teams or free for all. Teams can be any of 2v2, 2v2v2, 3v3. (With expansions up to 12 players for up to 6 teams of 2, 4 teams of 3, 3 teams of 4 or 2 teams of 5-6)

Players have associated roles or abilities with their Kingdom of Healer, Tank or Fighter(With expansions to include the Punisher role, Engineer role and Conjurer role). The game includes the Moveable Target™ mechanic where players will all attack at once or without order by throwing rings at opponent's kingdom boards. Once the battle round ends, results are scored and play continues until the phase ends. There is a store or decision phase between battle rounds for players to make choices to obtain more rings and/or defensive targets and/or offensive targets and/or morale to steer their game play as they desire.

The goal is to earn Victory Points by surviving and defeating your enemies. At the end of the game the player or team with the most Victory Points wins the game.

Expansions include variations of capture the flag, castling, demolition, death match, defeat the leader, and multiple types of combat phases.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Fantasy, Fighting, Horror, Medieval, Pirates, Real-time, Religious, Science Fiction, Zombies
mechanics: Player Elimination, Role Playing, Simulation, Team-Based Game, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Shape the Economy
description:
Shape the Economy is a game of strategic buying and selling.
Players own companies and have a store front and an investment center. Invest in a company to become part owner or co-owner. Make money from other players by investing in other companies or selling your product to other companies.

The winner of the game is the player that is first to become co-owner of two other companies. Or the first to make X amount of money depending on players playing.

It is a 2-6 player game with 4 player and 6 player variations.
If playing with 2-3 players the game requires bot companies. If playing with 5 players the game will require one bot company.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Industry / Manufacturing, Negotiation
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Tile Placement, Trading

name: Thunder Lanes USA
description:
Hear The Roar. Feel The Thunder! The Nasty-Car Lane Racing Game!

Two to eight players race a stock car team of three cars in a lane changing and drafting battle of twenty-four cars at the Thunder Valley Raceway.

On a players turn they will play a card to move either their own or opponents car forward the amount of spaces forward whilst also drafting that same amount of rear cars. Only cars in the outer lanes can be moved forward. Players complete their turn by swapping lanes of one of their own cars with an adjacent car of another color.

Wild cards may move any color car and Spin cards can be used to spinout opponents or even your own car!

Points are awarded to the highest placed cars at three stages throughout the race. The player with the team that has the most total points after all Race cards have been played wins!

name: Die Reise durch die Schweiz
description: This is a simple roll and move game that starts in Basel. The first player to reach space 60 (Schaffhausen) wins the game. On some spaces, events hinder or benefit the players.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Schuss und Tor
description:
Each player has 25 cards. The game consists of 2 halfs (f. e. 2 x 15 minutes). After the first half all cards are returned to the hand of the players. The player who scores the most goals wins the game.

The 5 goalkeeper-cards of each player are shuffled and placed topdown in 2 stacks on the spaces 1 (goal) of the game board.

The 20 fieldplayer-cards of each player are shuffled and 10 cards are placed topdown on the spaces 2-11 on each side of the gamebord. The other 10 cards (reserve) get on the hand of each player.

The starting player (chosen randomly) turns over one of his cards on spaces 7-11 the board. The now revealed card requires a reaction (turning of a card) of an chosen opponent (straight or diagonal ahead).

The two cards are compared and the inferior one is placed beside the game board to build a new stack of reserve cards.
The superior card is moved to the space of the inferior card and may continue to attack another opponent card. If a attacking card is countered by a defending card, both cards are removed from the board and the opponent player gets his opening turn to attack.

Before each opening turn, the player places reserve cards he choses from his hand onto the free spaces on his half of the game board.

The rules are summarized on each side of the game board.

name: ねこまねき (Neko-Maneki)
description:
User summary
ねこまねき (Neko-Maneki) is a Japanese card game of accumulating cats (neko).

Who is the one to be the best cat partner?
Try to play items that won't overlap with other players, and get the cat!
A simple butting game!

'Butting' is a Japanese game for the cancelling out method used games like What the Heck?. in Neko-Maneki, players choose a card face-down from their hand of five. They want to collect the cat card turned up from the draw pile by matching with their hand card.

But if any players match cards, they discard their card. Of the remaining, the highest ranked card collects, if it matches. Players score points for getting cats. Most points wins when the draw pile is out.

Gameplay follows the typical double-think needed for this style of game. But the game holds a little more than mere bluff.

Publisher's summary
ねこたちといちばん仲良くなれるのは誰か？
アイテムを被らないように出して、ねこをゲット！
お手軽バッティングゲーム！

name: トーテムのこころ (Spirit of Totem)
description:
In トーテムのこころ (Spirit of Totem), players attempt to create a totem pole from cards before anyone else. Most cards depict one or three color-coded spirit icons at the top of the card, with the colors being repeated at the bottom of the card as well; a few cards picture a thunderbird, and these cards are used to top a totem or cast a spell.

Each player starts with two cards in hand, and on a turn first draws one card, then plays or discards one card. When they play a totem card, they can start a totem or add to a totem — but when adding to a totem at least one of the colored marks on the card being added must be placed in the same column as the card being covered, even if this means the card being placed doesn't line up exactly with the card below. If the top card shows red, yellow, blue, and you want to add a yellow, brown, blue, then you can line up the yellow marks or the blues, but not both.

When a player plays a thunderbird, they can cast one of the four spells in play, after which that spell is placed face down until all four spells have been cast, after which they're all revealed once again. The spells are "Wind blows left/right", "Zap", and "Gift". The caster of the wind spell chooses a height above the first level, then all cards at the level and above are shifted one column left or right, depending on the wind. If parts of a totem have no support, then those cards are discard. Zap removes the top card in a player's totem, and Gift requires each player to pass one card in hand left and the other right.

As soon as a totem consists of at least four cards and the top card is centered with the bottom card (regardless of the positioning of the intervening cards), the player can top the totem with a thunderbird card to win the game. If the player has an earth totem on top — that is, a card showing the same spirit icon in all three spots, then the totem doesn't need to be aligned to be topped with a thunderbird.

トーテムのこころ (Spirit of Totem) also includes rules for solo play, with the player needing to build totems of 7, 8, 9, and 10 cards without the use of spells in order to win.
mechanics: Hand Management, Pattern Building, Take That

name: Speed Clay Maker
description: In Speed Clay Maker, players use clay to create subjects within a limited amount of time. Each player then answers what subject they think the modeler designed. If they're correct, both modeler and the answerer score a point. Once each player has the modeler/question maker once, the game ends and whoever has the most points wins.

name: Planar Expedition
description:
Description from the publisher:

Planar Expedition is a fantasy board game where players will traverse through the lands of Evyllon in search of the planar portal. Upon entering the plane, players will battle their way to challenge and defeat the Supreme and save Evyllon. With a personal quest, along with many side quests and random encounters, players will strategically and heroically fight many different foes using a card based battle system.
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Storytelling

name: Animal Buddy: India Edition Board Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

An all-new Indian jungle safari board game from the KAADOO- PLAY & LEARN SERIES. Designed for smaller children, aged 4 and above. It is for two players, simple and loads of fun.

Very easy game rules let the tiny ones get into the game quickly. Players can decide between them on who starts a game. Players advance by picking a card and following the instructions on the card picked; no dice is thrown.There are also experiences along the route that the players can look forward to. The player who comes out of the forest first is the winner.

This is an exciting game that children would want to play again and again. They can play it with very little help from adults. Kaadoo Animal Buddy is pure thrill.

This game will help children in a number of ways:

Helps improve social skills, be it playing with siblings or friends
In a rule-filled real world, helps them understand how to play by rules
Helps improve their visual IQ and fires up their imagination as they sight various exotic animals, birds and reptiles in the forest
Helps grow their knowledge about wildlife; generate interest in nature and conservation. The very essence of Play & Learn !

name: Animal Buddy: Africa Edition Board Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

An all-new African jungle safari board game from the KAADOO- PLAY & LEARN SERIES. Designed for smaller children, aged 4 and above. It is for two players, simple and loads of fun.

Very easy game rules let the tiny ones get into the game quickly. The players can decide between them on who starts a game. Players advance by picking a card and following the instructions on the card picked; no dice is thrown. There are also experiences along the route that the players can look forward to. The player who comes out of the forest first is the winner.

This is an exciting game that children would want to play again and again. They can play it with very little help from adults. Kaadoo Animal Buddy is pure thrill.

This game will help children in a number of ways:

Helps improve social skills, be it playing with siblings or friends
In a rule-filled real world, helps them understand how to play by rules
Helps improve their visual IQ and fires up their imagination as they sight various exotic animals, birds and reptiles in the forest
Helps grow their knowledge about wildlife; generate interest in nature and conservation. The very essence of Play & Learn!

name: Explore Wild Australia: The Land Down Under
description:
Description from the publisher:

Kaadoo: your nature safari on the go! Now, tame the vast, wild Australian outbacks !

The Australian Outback spans around 6.5 million square kilometres from east to west, and from north to south. It covers several climate zones and experiences a wide range of temperatures.

Play the Explore WILD AUSTRALIA - The Land Down Under Premium Edition boardgame and get to meet interesting ‘people’ who live on land, in water or in the air, such as kangaroos, wallabies, kookaburras, platypuses, crocodiles and deadly snakes. This is a well-researched and very unique compilation. Experience an exotic, vibrant biosphere, right at your home.


Fun and educational wildlife safari board game for children and the whole family. Ideally suited for children aged 6 to 12 years
One-of-a-kind board game created by wildlife photographer and enthusiast Diinesh Kumble; approved and co-branded by the World Wildlife Fund [WWF] India
A game for everyone, offering hours of group play, driving through the jungle, discovering amazing wild beasts and facing the ups and downs of a safari
Offers quick set up and easy understanding for kids and yet involves strategic thinking on the use of cards to alter game status
Educates children on the flora and fauna and develops in them a taste for nature and wildlife
Makes a unique and outstanding gift

name: Lion's Den: Western India Edition Board Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

Kaadoo: your nature safari on the go! Get up close with the king of the jungle, in the sprawling Gir Forest National Park, Gujarat

Fun and educational wildlife safari board game for children and the whole family. Ideally suited for children aged 6 to 12 years
One-of-a-kind board game created by wildlife photographer and enthusiast Diinesh Kumble; approved and co-branded by the World Wildlife Fund [WWF] India
A game for everyone, offering hours of group play, driving through the jungle, discovering amazing wild beasts and facing the ups and downs of a safari
Offers quick set up and easy understanding for kids and yet involves strategic thinking on the use of cards to alter game status
Educates children on the flora and fauna and develops in them a taste for nature and wildlife
Makes a unique and outstanding gift

name: Oceanic Wonder
description:
Description from the publisher:

Kaadoo: your nature safari on the go! Now, explore the mighty oceans and get up close with a bewildering range of oceanic life forms!

Did you know that 90% of the earth's biosphere is oceanic? And that is also about 71% of earth's surface. Despite, how much do we know about the creatures that live in the seas ?. Come, join us in the Oceanic Wonder [Premium Edition] boardgame. Let's go on an expedition in cute little boats and meet the sharks, octopuses, dolphins, crustaceans etc. and of course, different kinds of fish. This is an awe-inspiring and unforgettable trek. In order to make it as interesting to you as our other 'land' safari games, we have designed the game board with an ocean track. Keep sailing and keep discovering !


Fun and educational wildlife safari board game for children and the whole family. Ideally suited for children aged 6 to 12 years
One-of-a-kind board game created by wildlife photographer and enthusiast Diinesh Kumble; approved and co-branded by the World Wildlife Fund [WWF] India
A game for everyone, offering hours of group play, driving through the jungle, discovering amazing wild beasts and facing the ups and downs of a safari
Offers quick set up and easy understanding for kids and yet involves strategic thinking on the use of cards to alter game status
Educates children on the flora and fauna and develops in them a taste for nature and wildlife
Makes a unique and outstanding gift

name: Wolves' Lair: North America Edition Board Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

Be the first to collect all the big animals hidden in the pack. The charismatic but elusive Wolf cards will be high on your mind, as you outmaneuver your opponents even while discovering other beautiful animals of North America.
Fun and educational wildlife safari board game for children and the whole family. Ideally suited for children aged 6 to 12 years
One-of-a-kind board game created by wildlife photographer and enthusiast Diinesh Kumble; approved and co-branded by the World Wildlife Fund [WWF] India
A game for everyone, offering hours of group play, driving through the jungle, discovering amazing wild beasts and facing the ups and downs of a safari
Offers quick set up and easy understanding for kids and yet involves strategic thinking on the use of cards to alter game status
Educates children on the flora and fauna and develops in them a taste for nature and wildlife
Makes a unique and outstanding gift

name: 123 / ABC
description:
A game designed to help children learn their numbers in a pair of games. The games are educational and aimed at the 3 - 8 age group.

In brief, it is a game to help small children read and count, usually solo but can be played with 2 or 3.

Each player takes a card and tries to read the letters on it (ABC) part, these start with three letters and are common objects such as B-E-E or C-A-T and go up from there depending on the age of the child.

The winner is the first player to get to a set number of correct answers, dependent on the age of the children. The track is a straight box divided into 12 squares for each color / team / player. Can be dependent on age so that younger children don't need to get as far as older ones.

On the 123 side each card has a number on it and picture of say 2 Dogs or 4 mice.

name: The Risen of 1948
description:
Set in 1948 in an Alternate History where Dragons had risen 5 years earlier during World War II to decimate most of the world's great cities. Armies made up of the remnants of world powers are making a last stand in this semi Co-operative Resource management, engine building, with area control and dice combat game.
Take to the air in experimental German planes, Use submarines to avoid detection from roaming dragons.

Three Dragons including the Mother are randomly placed on three major cities.

Players select their army and determine start order.
There is a card drafting phase where certain number of cards are drawn and the last player in turn order gets first pick of the cards and then passes to next turn ordered player and then back to them where everyone gets to keep two cards.
Now it is first players turn. They have a number of actions based on the number of Generals they started with. Each general can give one order Explore/Move, Mine, Sell/Trade, Build, Attack or Draw a Card. Early emphasis is on gathering resources to develop weapons and vehicles. Players will explore the globe and mine by flipping hex tiles. The revealed mine may have gold, oil, metal, uranium or it may be a dragon cave and unleash a new dragon. The new dragon will immediately fly around the board. It's direction will be dictated by a 4 sided die. It will only stop when it reaches a city or player who will have to fight it. If too many cities are captured the game immediately ends and all players lose.

As player armies start to get stronger it is advised that these players team up to start hunting dragons whose carcasses are a plethora of new resources: Scales, Blood and Hydrogen allowing very unique upgrade abilities. If the dragon had a city base, victorious players can turn over the tiles and reap the benefits.

Once players become strong enough they will attempt to defeat the Mother Dragon. If they poses a hydrogen or atom bomb they can do so but by destroying city they will not reap the treasures. The city being lost may also cost them the game if the limit is met. Once all dragons are destroyed players count their active mining territories, cities and gold to find out who is the new world super power and ultimate winner.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Dice, Economic, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures, Nautical, Science Fiction, World War II
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Semi-Cooperative Game, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Neues Deutches Flaggen-Spiel
description:
This is a dice-throwing gambling game with a fairly elaborate board. The board consists of a 100-space track divided into three areas.

The outer ring consists of 26 squares around the edge of the board, each showing the flag of a German royal realm, princedom, grand duchy or duchy, as well as those of the free cities Lubeck, Bremen and Hamburg and the (recently conquered) territory of Alsace-Lorraine. The second ring consists of small squares numbered 27-82 in a variety of colors including light and dark blue, red, green, yellow and white. The final ring is a circle numbered 83-99 which sits at the center of the board flanked on either side by soldiers on horseback and above and below by the rules. The 100 space is a coat of arms in the middle of the circle.

Players each start with the same amount of money and put an agreed sum into the pot. They take turns rolling a single die to move along the track. Players need to know the ranks of the various flags: they receive 3 marks from the pot when landing on a royal or duchy space, but must put 3 marks into the pot when landing on a princedom or grand duchy. The free city squares have no effect. Landing on the same space as another player also has no effect.

Landing on Alsace-Lorraine (12) or on the squares 30, 40, 50, 60 or 70 means going back to square 1 and starting over. A player who runs out of money is no longer allowed to play. Whoever gets to the 100 space first collects the pot.

name: Tarabish
description:
Tarabish, also known by its slang term Bish, is a trick-taking card game of complex rules derived from Belote, a game of the Jass family. The actual pronunciation of the name is "tar-bish", even though it can be spelled "tarabish". It is played primarily by the people of Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, in Canada, where it was brought in 1901 by a Lebanese immigrant George Shebib.

The game is over when one or both teams accumulate 500 points or more. Points are counted at the end of each hand and both teams always count their points. The team with the most points at the end of the game wins.

A Tarabish deck consists of a normal deck of playing cards with the 2 through 5 of each suit removed. In preparation for the hand the dealer shuffles the cards in the usual manner. When finished the person to the right of the dealer cuts the cards. The cut must leave at least four cards in each portion of the deck. Once the cards have been cut, no further shuffling is allowed.

The 36 Tarabish cards are dealt in groups of three beginning to the left of the dealer and proceeding clockwise until all the cards are passed out. The four players look at their first six cards; the last three, called the kitty, remain face down until after the bid is complete and a trump suit has been chosen.

Cards value
The cards have a strict point value in trumps:

J = 20 points
9 = 14 points
A = 11 points
10 = 10 points
K = 4 point
Q = 3 point
8 7 6 = no value
The order and value in a non-trump suit are:

A = 11 points
10 = 10 points
K = 4 points
Q = 3 points
J = 2 points
9 8 7 6 = no value

name: Der kluge Sparer
description:
Each player gets an bank account and pocket money. There is also a joint account. Each player has to get from space 1 to space 120 (Raiffeisen symbol). Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events benefit or hinder the players, mostly by gaining or losing money. The first player to reach space 120 gets half of the joint account, the next one half of the rest and so on. The player with the most money wins the game.

The playing money pictures Deutsche Mark banknotes that were first issued 1961 and 1963.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Empire Legacy
description:
Two players face off in an awesome duel as Empires that are trying to make each other fall.

Two teams of that included 5 champions of different kinds.

A Giant a dwarf, Mage Elf, And the Emperor fight, for what they think is right. Use different abilities and moves to destroy your enemy. Keep your champions hidden, so they can come in the best time possible.

Each team has 5 champions that they keep hidden to surprise there opponent in a bad situation

Kill your opponents Emperor first to win.

name: Mots Croisés Nathan
description:
Loosely based on the game crosswords but this version is played with a fixed board and it doesn't involve rolling a cube, players pull word tiles from the box and then lay them on the board forming words to score points
The highest points scorer is the winner.

name: Ski-Daddle
description:
A ski race game for the fun of it! A game of skill, steady hands, and fast competition.

2 Racing Slopes
2 Racing Balls

Object - To be the first player to roll his Racing Ball through the course.

Start - Each player selects a Slope and Ball. The balls are placed in the number 1 holes on each Slope. The race begins.

Race Procedure - Each player flips his ball into the air and catches it on the Slope. The Ball is then rolled over the Slope to Hole #2. From there is is rolled to Holes #3 and #4. The first player to reach Hole #4 wins.

Hands - A player may reposition his hand(s) at any time during the race. However at no time can the Ball touch a hand. If this occurs the Ball must be placed in the last corner hole reached before the player can continue.

If Ball Falls Off Slope - If the Ball falls through a hole or off the Slope it must be returned to the last corner hole occupied. For example, if the Ball falls off the Slope while on its way from Hole #3 to Hole #4 it must be placed back in #3 before the player can proceed. The Ball must come to a complete rest in each corner hole before it can be flipped out.

Course - A player does not have to follow a prescribed course. He may flip, bounce or roll the Ball between corners in any manner that suits his temperament.

name: The Media Game
description:
The Media Game was inspired by Careers and was designed by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) as a teaching tool for their National Spot Sales department.

The object of the game is to earn the greatest number of Market Share Units and Media Efficiency Units by going through various "clients". At the end of the game the player who has the greatest number of Units and Profits will be the winner of the game.

Players move around the board by the value of one of two dice (player's choice). Depending on which square they land on, they will either receive 'credits' or 'penalties'. There are three types of "units" a player can gain points in and a player scores their lowest of these three, so they must try to maximize each unit type equally in order to win. Random effects through the drawing of event cards will also occur. While each player has little control over which credits and penalties they receive in the game, the overall purpose of The Media Game is educational. It was designed for employees of the CBC Sales department as a way to make them familiar with company terminology, policies, and marketing strategies.

name: Halmstad: Spelet om din stad
description:
Part of the "Spelet om din stad" series about Swedish cities.
The game is kind of monopoly, with minor rule variations, located in Halmstad.
Release 2007 during Halmstads 700 year anniversary.

name: Wager of the Gods: Hades vs. Poseidon
description:
In the timeless realm of the Greek gods, Zeus reigns supreme. His resentful brothers, Hades and Poseidon, often find themselves bored, and squabble about their lesser status. To settle matters, albeit temporarily, they occasionally wager on events in the human sphere. On this day, they’re betting for boasting rights on three separate races: a Greek chariot race c. 350 BC, a trail run in present-day Idaho, USA, and a space-faring contest at light-speed in the year 4017. Naturally, the sneaky duo will try to influence the outcome of the contests, while Zeus keeps a watchful eye on their activities.

Wager of the Gods is unique in that players will simultaneously need to manage three distinct races, each with its own rigors and pitfalls. Movement is generated by multi-numbered chit draw; these numbers must be allocated to each of the three game boards. Naturally there are occasional special actions -- and just the right amount of strategy for a tense and fun two-player game. The player who wins two of the three races wins the day!

Components:

• 3 Game Boards
• 70 Action Counters
• 6 Player Tokens in two colors
• 4 Galaxy Counters
• 8 Whip Counters
• 6 Ram Counters
• 1 Dolphin Counter
• 2 Reference Cards
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Take That

name: Turn
description:
2 players Dark and Light

Materials
8x8 checkerboard
56 bi-color pieces
A supply of plastic rings

Object
The game ends with victory for the first player that makes a four in a row; consisting of friendly ringed or non-ringed pieces that are orthogonally or diagonally adjacent. Otherwise, the player still able to move is the winner.

Setup
Stack the 56 pieces on the border spaces in an alternating pattern of black and white. There should be face-up a black-sided piece and a white-sided piece per space.

Play
One player plays black the other white, both share the plastic rings.

Decide who goes first in any convenient manner, turns then alternate.

On a turn,
1) Move a "naked" friendly piece across empty squares in a straight orthogonal line from the border onto an empty square or
2) Move a "naked" friendly piece in a straight orthogonal line, moving over no more than one enemy piece and no further than the empty square behind that jumped piece. The moving piece must end up with at least one orthogonal or diagonal neighbor. You can optionally flip the piece just moved to your opponent’s color and then place a plastic ring over the piece, making it permanent. Once this happens, any orthogonally or diagonally adjacent "naked" pieces are also flipped.

Restrictions
A player may not repeat the board position of the previous turn.
mechanics: Enclosure, Grid Movement, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Spring Coming Baseball
description:
Spring Coming Baseball is a fast play statistical replay game by Roberto Chiavini (but not so fast, as you roll for each inning for each team, to get the number of hits and run for each inning), with individual yearbook for a huge plethora of leagues.

Teams are rated for Offense and Defense, and the total of the two ratings are combined to highlight a column on the Hits grid. A roll of two six sided dice, potentially modified by a roll of the ten sided "Third Die", produces a number of hits for the half inning being played.

Then, for each hit, a percentile roll versus the batting team's Conversion Percentage is made determining whether that hit produces a run.

Repeating this process for each half inning, individual games can be played in minutes, and seasons (or post-seasons) in a single sitting.

The basic game comes with a rulebook and the 12 seasons of the All American Girls League, 1943-54.

As well as the complete history of both the National and American Major Leagues, the following yearbooks are also available:
American Association, 1946, 1947 and 1948
Big South League 1996 and 1997
Canadian Baseball League 2003
Dixie Association 1971
Federal League 1914 and 1915
Inter American League 1979
International League 1965 and 1966
Lone Star League 1977
Mexican League 1955
National Association 1871, 1872, 1873, 1874 and 1875
North American League 2011 and 2012
Pacific Coast League 1952, 1953, 1954, 1955, 1956 and 1957
Pecos League 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015 and 2016
South Atlantic League 1963
South Coast League 2007
Texas League 1950, 1951 and 1952

name: Sleepy Troll
description:
Don't let Troll's adorableness fool you; those clawed hands are for more than just clutching his teddy bear. As a thief, pillage the beast's den and steal as much of his gold as possible before he wakes. Troll's hoard holds treasure enough to make even paupers into kings.
But be careful, should he catch you carrying away his hard-stolen riches...Well, Sleepy Trolls also make terrifying Angry Trolls.

This light, press your luck game pits player against player as they attempt to steal the sleeping troll's gold. The game begins with one player drawing cards from a single, 99 card deck in the center of the table. He or she may grab any number of cards, but if an Angry Troll cards is pulled, he or she loses all of the drawn cards from that turn. Angry Troll Cards may be mitigated by one of the limited Sword and Shield Cards in the deck. Players may also steal from their fellow players using special action cards.

The game ends when players have gone through the entire deck. The player with the most amount of gold claims victory.

name: Adamastor: The Sea Monster
description:
ADAMASTOR is a Whimsical Competitive Boardgame of horrible sea monsters that live in the depths of the sea, where the Atlantic meets the Indian Ocean, fighting amongst each other to be the one that gets to skink the very unfortunate ships that atempt to cross the Cape of Torments.

---

The game of ADAMASTOR is played with 2 to 4 players. Each game lasts 5 rounds (6 with 2 players), at the end of which the
player with the most total of Victory points (VP) is the winner of the game.

Each player controls one sea monster. Players use simultaneous card play to move their monsters on the
board and attack ships and other player’s monsters. The cards chosen cards also determine the turn order (the better the actions, the slower you are). Players score victory points either by sinking the Portuguese
fleet or by knocking down other sea Monsters or by completing variable objectives that make each game feel different. At the end of each round players will each choose and gain a new action card that provides them with better Monster Actions for the following rounds.

---

Adamastor is a card-driven simultaneous action selection game with fast paced mechanic and a modular board that keeps every game fun and fresh.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: The Guvnor
description:
OVERVIEW
The GUVNOR is a gangster themed card trading game. Players trade crime cards simultaneously in order to gain RESPECT from the other players. The first player to win 30 RESPECT points wins the game.

GAMEPLAY
Players are dealt nine random CRIME cards at the start of the game and seven REPECT points. The dealer starts the trading by shouting 'LET'S DO BUSINESS' after which all players may trade cards face down across the table. The first player to collect nine identical CRIME cards shouts 'AVE SOME OF THAT!' to win the round. The winner of the round becomes The GUVNOR and receives a win bonus (PROFIT). All the other players then pay The GUVNOR one RESPECT point from their pile. Any players caught RED HANDED (i.e. they have six or more identical CRIME cards in their hand) pay a penalty. The GUVNOR then takes a DECREE card from a wild deck - it may effect them directly or it may be used to hindered/help another player. The CRIME cards are then returned, shuffled and the next round begins.

name: The Bulldog Game
description: The Bulldog Game is a spin & move game of collecting bones for 2-4 players. It is labeled as "A child's first strategy game" for ages 5-9.

name: 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea
description:
The game 20,000 Leagues under the Sea by Jaymar games is based on Walt Disney’s first sci-fi film of the same name.

Players begin by spinning the Nautilus (Captain Nemo’s Machine) to indicate the moving of their pieces. The spinner contains R’s and L’s for Right and Left moves. In front of each letter is a number specifying the amount in which to move. The rows of the board signify depth and are marked with a few special spaces.

When a player lands on ‘purple arrow’ spaces, he submerges to the next level down and spins again.
When a player lands on a ‘green starfish’, he submerges two levels down or an additional 2000 leagues under the sea and spins again. If the space is occupied by another player, though, he rises to the space above.
When a player lands on a ‘red octopus’, he rises 1000 leagues directly above the space. He does not spin again.

Whenever a player lands on a space occupied by another player, he rises to the space directly above.

The object of the game is to be the first player to reach ’20,000 leagues under the sea’ to the treasure chest at the bottom. The player must land on the red arrow.

Box cover may vary.

name: The Good Old Game of Proverbs
description:
The game consists of 96 small cards, each with a Proverb written upon it.

One player is selected to leave the room and be the Guesser.
All other players choose one of the Proverbs from the box.
Each of these players, in order, are given ONE word from the chosen Proverb, and then the Guesser is invited back in.

The Guesser is then to ask one player at a time a Question. The player must answer him, but he must include the word from the Proverb he was given, in his answer.
The Guesser continues asking Questions to players, to which they answer with inclusion of the given Proverb word, until the Guesser can figure out and cite The Proverb.
The player who gave the final answer, which allowed the Guesser to cite the correct Proverb, is then the Guesser, and play repeats.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: RollOut Game
description:
RollOut game combines classic cards with dice. The game features a custom deck of 50 cards A-11 all suits and 6 WILD cards. Each card in the deck has a matching dice value. A=1 2=2 etc. The objective is for the players to 'RollOut' their hand before their opponents.

Players will ante in a counter or a chip and that will allow the player to see one round of rolls, hopefully creating a better chance of winning the pot. If you roll the desired number in your hand and play no other player can play. If you roll a number and and do not have it, any other player can play their matching card.

Each round of antes starts after the dealer rolls and players decide if they are going to stay in and play or they will fold. If the player decides to stay they will anti and have another chance to 'RollOut'

If a player rolls 'snake eyes' double ones they are out of the hand. If a player rolls double six they automatically win. The WILD card can only be played on your turn and had the ability to prevent other players from playing their card.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Dice, Educational, Math
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck

name: Pike's Peak or Bust
description:
Small Pins are strategically positioned on an image of the mountain. This is the board. The starting Pin is marked base, and the Game’s Goal Pin, obviously at the Peak, is marked top. A player’s objective is to reach the TOP by spanning his Metal Traveler from Pin to Pin.

Attached to the board is a Metal Traveler on a string. This Traveler has rings on each side that are used to encircle the Pins on the board. Starting from the base, a player positions his Traveler and encircles another Pin with the other end of his Traveler in order to move and climb to the summit.

The Traveler spans easily to any pin, from pin to pin. A player does not need to force any Traveler span to move.

The player who reaches the top of Pike's Peak first wins the game

name: Game of Farmer Trott
description:
Each player takes a Character card.

The 48 cards that have items written on them are placed face down in the center of players. An example of items on the cards are, A piece of beef, Two little pigs, A pound of candles, A bottle of hair oil, Two spools of cotton and other similar needs of the time to go shopping for.

Three questions are asked to player on his turn.

The first is ‘Where did you go shopping?’ The player answers with any place he wants. He could say ‘I want gone shopping at the Grocer, Butcher, Hardware Store, the Mill, or wherever’. After he answers, he is asked the second question, ‘What did you buy?’

This question prompts him to choose one center card. He reads it, and if he couldn’t have purchased the item at the store previously named, he is punished; unless, he can justify it. For example, if he says he went shopping at the Butcher Shop, surely he did not purchase Two pounds of Yarn there. However, he may come up with an explanation of how the Butcher’s Wife changed her mind on the color of yarn she had purchased earlier, and sold it to them instead of returning it to the store.

If all players agree with the explanation, he is not punished. The third question is now asked, ‘What do you intend to do with it?’ If the player cannot come up with a wise answer, then the player is punished for ‘extravagance’.

The winner is the first player who succeeds in plausibly answering all three questions. He now becomes Farmer Trott, and the game begins again.

name: Where's Johnny
description:
The game begins with the dealer taking out one card from the entire deck for each person playing. One of these must be the lone Johnny card. These special cards are shuffled and placed on top of the remaining deck. All cards are then dealt to players, one by one, facedown into piles. Although it is not known who has the Johnny card, it is known one of the player’s piles includes it at the bottom.

Counters, either beans or buttons, are also passed out. Each player receives ten counters. Approximately twenty-five counters are placed in the center of the table for all players to pay into, or take from; according to what their cards state.

Taking turns, players flip up the top card on their piles and place it in front of them. They read the card aloud for all to hear, and follow the instructions to ‘pay’ or ‘take’ counters.

he deck consists of one ‘Where is Johnny?’ card. When this card is turned over, the card is passed to each player for one round. Whoever holds the card during the round is free from making any payments into the center. He can receive, though.

Once the final Johnny card is flipped over by a player, the game ends. Whoever has the most counters at this time wins the game.

name: Komikal Konversation
description:
To play, questions and answer cards are divided evenly among the players; or a dealer could give all Question Cards to some players, and the others all Answer Cards. Either way, the cards remain face down in the two separate piles.

The game begins by the first player drawing a Question Card. He reads the question out loud for all to hear, and then ‘looks at’ any player he chooses to receive an Answer from. Whoever he ‘looks at’ draws an Answer card from the faced down pile, and reads the answer on the card. This is considered the answer to the question.

The player who gives the most correct answers wins.

name: Game of Favorite Art
description:
Favorite Art comprises of 56 cards depicting illustrations by various artists.
To begin, all cards are shuffled and dealt to the players. The person to the dealer’s left goes first and asks, from any player of choice, for a card to help complete a set in his hand.
The objective is to create sets (all four cards of an artist’s name). The winner of the game is the player with the most sets at the end of the game.

name: Deep Sea Rescue
description: This is a deep sea adventure themed childrens' trivia game system. There are multiple games included for this game system, including a trivia game and an adventure game

name: Easy Addition War
description: This is an educational game that is extremely similar to the classic children's card game of "War". In this game, each card's value is represented by a simple addition problem (e.g. 2+3). Each card also has a number of repetitive images on it that equal the card's value.

name: You who?
description: This canine detective themed young childrens' game is both a card and board game. Players make matches of cards in order to advance on a track on the board towards the finish line.

name: Listening Lotto: Faces & feelings
description:
In this educational children's game, players match narrative statements to photographs of kids’ faces showing different expressions. To play, players listen to the sounds on the CD and place tokens on the images on their game cards that match what they hear. Players win by matching the most images correctly.

Each game set includes 12 game cards with 8 photos per card, 120 game tokens, an audio CD, and directions in English.

name: Says Whooo?
description: In this owl themed childrens' game, players roll dice with letters on them. They then attempt to spell as many words as possible using the letters rolled.

name: Flip, Flip, Fall.
description: In this educational rhyming card game, each card is printed with a word. Players flip card over off the top of a face down stack of cards and then must compete with each other to be the first to rhyme the word shown to earn the card. Once a player has enough cards "their tower falls" and they win the game.

name: Pollywog
description:
Players match numerals to cards that have a set number of repeated images in this educational game that teaches numbers. The players lay down the matched sets to gain points.
Includes 52 cards and 1 die.

name: The Mummy's Tomb
description:
Players answer educational questions to explore or race on a modular board. This educational trivia and math question game has multiple game modes including racing and exploration variants.
Includes 73 items include, 1-32-page book, 12 game board cards, 54 game cards, 6 game pieces on one sheet

name: Keep rolling
description:
Dice game. Where players compete to get the highest total number by combining numbers rolled on dice with basic math operations including multiplication, addition.

This is a themeless educational logic game with elements of push your luck.
Box contains: 6 dice, 1 notepad and 1 pencil;2-4 Players
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck

name: Jungle rumble card game
description:
In this word finding game, each card has one letter on it. Players find words among the visible letters to earn tokens. The player with the most tokens wins the game.

Includes 52 game cards and 25 tokens.

name: Letter coaster
description: This is an educational card game that teaches alphabetization. Each card has a single letter on it. Players attempt to lay down all of their cards before a sand-timer runs out (and before any other player lays down all their cards) in order to win. Players lay down cards that are alphabetically one rank above or below the letter on the card shown on the top of the discard pile.

name: Fandango
description:
Fandango is a 4X style boardgame set in a classic fantasy universe, with some elements permanently changing from game to game (sort of like a legacy game, but with less story telling)

Players will play as gods that have made a bet between each other, to see who is the best at leading ANY faction to victory.
The winner of a campaign is the player that have accumulated most Victory Points throughout the entire campaign.

All factions have their own special powers, and have different core stats, offering a unique feel.

On a turn players in turnorder will move some of their troops, then after all players have moved, a round of combat will begin.
Once all combats have been resolved players will then gather ressources based on the regions they control.
And lastly players will if they have enough ressources be able to upgrade their units and recruit reinforcements.
Upgrades will remain in effect for the remainder of the campaign.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Game of Hens and Chickens
description:
Hens and Chickens consists of 49 cards, an indicator, and numbered counters. The counters are made up of tiny thick square pieces of paper which are marked with the numbers 1,2,3,5, or 10. The cards comprise of five different types of images.
There is one card displaying the image of Uncle Ned and one card displaying the image of a Fox. Then there are 8 Egg cards, 25 Chick cards, and 14 Hen cards.

The game begins by placing the Uncle Ned card in the center of all the players. Next, an appointed dealer will shuffle and equally distribute the other cards, including the fox card, to all the players.

The cards are stacked face up in front of each player. The counters are also equally distributed to the players based on their amounts. Each player should have the same number of cards and equal value of ‘counters’. Players then each place the amount of 10 in counters on Uncle Ned. He is considered the score-keeper.

The first player spins the indicator and adds the total pointed by both arrows. If this number is found on the player’s top card, he takes the value of 5 in counters from Uncle Ned. If the number spun does not appear on the player’s card, he gives the value of 2 in counters to Uncle Ned. The card is turned over.
The next player then spins, but adds his total to the previous player’s total spin, wrapping around at the number 15.
The winner of the game is the player with the most points/counter values after all cards have been used.

name: Storming the Castle
description:
The game comes with a piece of cardboard, three balls, and two wooden bases to put the game together.

Each player takes turns rolling the three balls up the drawbridges and into the openings: the castle entrances.

Based on the success of a player’s rolls, points are scored. Five points are given for each ball going through the outside entrances. Ten points are given for the center. If a ball falls into the Moat, five points are lost by a player. If a ball rolls back down the drawbridge, no points are given or lost.

The winner of the game is the player to first collect 200 points.

name: O'Grady's Goat
description:
The game of O’Grady’s Goat consists of a small pamphlet that contains a story with blank lines left in the tale. Also in the box are numerous cards with five phrases written upon them.

One player is chosen to be the main storyteller. This player will evenly deal out all phrase cards face down in a pile, in front of each player.
The storyteller will then begin reading the narrative provided in the pamphlet.
During the story, the reader pauses at each blank line shown in the tale. On this pause, players take turns quickly filling in the blanks by reading a phrase from their cards. The game is over when the story is completed.

name: Game of Wild Animals
description:
Thirty-six cards, displaying various creatures from all across the world are included.

The cards are divided into six different sets containing six animals from each of the set’s locations.
The object of the game is to collect as many complete sets as possible (called books), and have the most points.
Two of the sets (US East and US West) are worth two points.
The other four sets (Europe, Asia, Africa, and Polar Regions) are worth one point.
The winner is the player with the most points.

name: Jack and the Beanstalk Game
description:
One player is the Giant and the other player is Jack. The game pieces are of two different colors. But, more appropriately, they are also two different sizes. The large piece represents the Giant, and the small piece represents Jack.

Jack is safe from the Giant if he rests on any red space. The Giant cannot land on these red spaces and must pass over them.

Players may move in any direction around the paths. They are not allowed to ‘pass’ each other.

Each player starts on his home space/star. They then take turns spinning the spinner and move accordingly. Jack needs to reach the Red Star of the Giant’s castle, and return home, without being caught by the Giant, in order to win. The Giant wins if he is able to land on the space Jack is on, by an exact spin.

name: Across the Sea
description:
Taking turns rolling the dice and moving their pieces accordingly, the players race to the center of the spirals. The first player to reach either Calcutta (on the red track) or Maskat (on the blue track) wins the game.

In a two player game, if a player lands on a black dotted space, he moves ahead four spaces. In a three to four player game, if a player lands on a black dotted space, he is considered on a ‘safety spot’. During a three to four player game, if a player is overtaken by another player, and not sitting on a safety spot, then that player must move his piece back to the nearest space with a black dot.

The player who reaches either Calcutta or Maskat first wins the game.

name: Jeu des Fleurs
description:
A total of 40 different flowers are printed in chromolithography, grouped into 10 sets.

At the start of the game all cards are distributed evenly among the player who keep them hidden for the other players.

Over three rounds the players try to play their cards in front of them, the player who manages to get rid of his hand cards the first wins the game.

name: Bump it!
description:
In this bumper car themed children's card game each card has two simple math equations. Players must match cards based on the answer to the math equations.

The game has a sand timer. Players must race match enough cards to avoid being eliminated by other players "bumped out" before the timer runs out.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math

name: Recreo Infantil
description:
Card game published in Gerona, Spain at the end of the 19th century.
Each card shows a letter or syllable in the top corners, vowel permutations for consonants, a series of images whose names in Spanish commence with that letter or syllable, and a miniature playing card in the center.
